Fredericton, N.B.
August 26, 1933.

To Hon. T. G. Murphy, M.P.,
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I have been informed that Mrs. Regina McElligott is an applicant for the position of teacher of the Indian School at North Devon.

I have known Mrs. McElligott for several years. I have known of her great success as a teacher in the Public Schools of New Brunswick and it is with pleasure I recommend her for the above named position.

I believe Mrs. McElligott to be competent, conscientious painstaking, a woman who, if successful in securing this position, would fill it very satisfactorily.

(Sgd.) A.S. McFarlane.
Chief Superintendent of Education.
MEMORANDUM

June 14th, 1934.

Dr. McGill,

In connection with the appointment of Mrs. Regina M. McElligott as a teacher in the Indian Day School at North Devon, I am enclosing, for your information, copies of certificates issued by Dr. A.E. McFarlane, Chief Superintendent of Education for the Province of New Brunswick, and by Mr. R.D. Hanson, Supervisor of Public Schools at Fredericton.

Private Secretary.
NORTH DEVON, N. B.
18th, 1934.

Department of Indian Schools,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sirs:

I have received a notice that I will not be continued as teacher in the Devon Indian School after the close of the present term.

I have been over twenty (20) years in the service. Will you kindly let me know what arrangement there is for pension under such circumstances.

I trust that this will be provided for as it will be urgently needed.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa.

Dear Sirs,

Last year I recommended for the position of Indian Teacher for the Severn Reservation, Miss Constance Murphy of my parish. Miss Hughes was returning the school for another year so the appointment was not made. As spiritual leader to the Indians and therefore believed education, I consider my recommendation the highest you can receive. As a young and modern teacher high grade is requested.

I wish to state that Miss Murphy fulfils all these. I refer you to my letter of last year. I trust the Department will have the courtesy of considering the influence of the French Fathers as well as his right in making the appointment.

Respectfully Yours,

[Signature]

July 31st

W. M. St. John
North Western N.B.

Ottawa, July 6, 1934.

Madam:

With reference to your letter of the 15th ultimo, I beg to say that there is no superannuation provided for teachers of Indian day schools.

The only provision we can make, under the requirements of the Auditor General, is two months' retiring gratuity. A cheque for $150 is therefore being issued and sent to you.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Miss Mary T. Hughes,
North Devon,
N.B.
Ottawa, July 6, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the St. Mary's Indian Day School.

Mrs. Regina McElligott has already been appointed as teacher of this school for the academic year 1934-35.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. W. M. Donahoe,
North Devon,
N.B.
The Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter informing me that an appointment has been made to the Indian School on the reservation under my spiritual direction I wish to state that the absurdity of the appointment has made a profound impression upon all (with the exception of the few who have heard of it). The lady appointed attended Normal School thirty-eight years ago and has not taught in New Brunswick or elsewhere for more than twenty-five years.

She was recommended by Mr. Macdonald, the Chief Superintendent of Education for N.B., a man whom I doubt went to school at the same time as she, but who can run very well. She qualifies for a teacher according to modern systems. Miss Hughes was dismissed on account of her inability to use modern methods, although she has been in active service for many years. Your correspondence last year informs me that a young and up-to-date teacher is needed. Someone must be engaged. All the foregoing is which Fr. Ryan and the Sisters in charge believe.
Spiritual welfare, which includes education, have been trying to build up for many years have been ignored for political favoritism. I wish to state that you have made a very unpopular appointment. I make no reference unfavorable to the lady appointed, but I am writing regarding to the disregard of the principles advocated last year in your correspondence regarding the school.

Yours truly,

W. M. Doucette

July 15th 1934
Dear Sir:

Yours of the 6th ultimo, duly received. I thank you for the cheque for $150 as a token of gratuity.

As to your statement that there is no pension for teachers of Indian Day, which I am not only surprised, but very much distressed by the announcement.

I have given the best part of my life and energy to the teaching of Indian children, and I firmly assert that my school has always been equal to the best, and second to none of the Indian schools in the province, during my 23 years in your service, and I was still willing to continue in your service.

I not only acted in the capacity of teacher, but have been as well a missionary to the Indian children, teaching them...
this prayers, catechism, Bible history, as well as preparing them to make their "First Holy Communion." In fact my whole life for the last 23 years had been devoted entirely to the Indian children, not only in schools but also any evenings and Saturdays was given to this interest.

Now, that I have been thrown out of my work in times of great depression, I am placed in a very grave position, since I feel it would be practically impossible for me to obtain another position. Therefore, I think that you should feel it your duty to grant me a suitable yearly allowance of at least $600 for my support.

Yours very truly,

Mary T. Hughes.
Fredericton Aug 24th 1934

Sir

I beg to ask the Department if Miss Mary T Hughes returned the School Register of 1933 and 1934 to the Department if so could it be returned to me Mrs Mc Elligott who is going to teach in the St Marys Indian School would like to have it she would then be in a position to place the scholars in their proper places that is the grades they belong.

Your obedient Servent

B J Griffiths
Indian Agent

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF REV. F. C. RYAN,
INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS FOR NEW BRUNSWICK, ON THE ST. MARY'S INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

-- DATE OF INSPECTION SEPT. 24, 1934 --

TEACHER - MRS. REGINA McELLIGOTT.

Mrs. McElligott has just taken charge of this school. She replaced Miss Hughes, being appointed to the said school by the Ind. Dept. I, as the Inspector of Ind. Schools for N.B., had no say in this appointment whatever. I desired a 1st class teacher and have tried in the good interest of this school for years to get such a teacher but failed. I had no other aim in view than that which I hold for every Ind. School in N.B., namely, the advancement of our Indians.

I found the pupils did not forget much of last year's work. They are bright, and with a good teacher should do well. About all grades were at review work.

In all truthfulness, I never saw or experienced such disorder in a school. I could not carry on the examination without calling the school to order on three or four occasions. I finally had to stop, and explained to the whole school that unless better order was maintained the school might as well be closed. The teacher claimed that they were much better now than when she opened school, some 4 weeks ago. Then I spoke strongly to the pupils, explaining that never in all the years that I had visited this school did I ever see anything disorderly, and was at a loss to know why such conduct was shown. All pupils were freely talking, no class would stand in line. One little boy hit another and tumbled him to the floor. Such a schoolroom! Considering all this, where, in the past, I ever found the best of order, my heart was broken. I can do nothing under such conditions, nor can the school advance until order is maintained, and a proper teacher installed.
I found the pupils, as a whole, very untidy compared with the past record of this school.

Mrs. McElligott informed me that she sent for the required material and when it arrived all will begin to knit and sew. The next four or five months will better explain just what progress will be made in this branch of our important work by our new teacher.

Had the choice of a teacher been left to me, as has been done in the past, I can assure the Dept. I could never have considered for one moment this appointment. Time will tell who is right or wrong. I have had vast experience for nearly 20 years in dealing with teachers and can say that I never allowed any favour nor condition to swerve me from the path of justice in giving to our Indians of N.B. the best. I have not a teacher outside of Mrs. McElligott but well knows if their school work is not well done they must be prepared to take another school, and it is only in this light that one can expect a teacher to advance her pupils, but when a teacher holds her position through "politics", quite independent to the Inspector of Schools, little progress can be expected. There I am speaking of our Indians Schools. They are so different in all respects of government to our white schools. Our white schools are carefully watched over by the ratepayers, trustees - who are near the school and constantly in touch with all working conditions of their school and teacher - competent persons to judge, and all this has a deep bearing on the teacher. It is not thus, however, in our Ind. Schools. Unless, therefore, there exists a medium between the Ind. Dept. and the Ind. School, competent in every respect to bridge over this gap, it is most evident our Indian Schools must retrograde, and in less than five years Indian Education in N.B. would only be in name.

I am most sorry, not for myself but for this school, that the Indian Dept. for some reason of its own has appointed the said teacher to St. Mary's Indian School.

(Sgd.) F. O. Ryan.
Dear Sirs:

As I have received no reply to my letter of Aug. 15th, concerning the request which I made to you, of granting me a yearly allowance of at least $600. for my support, in recognition of my twenty-three years' good and faithful work in your service, therefore I feel the urgent necessity of repeating my request.

If I had spent those years of service in the Public Schools of the province, I would now, like other teachers of New Brunswick, be eligible for a pension, and so would have a means of livelihood, in these times of such great depression. But this is now lost to me, as I have already asserted to you, my school was equal to the best and
second to none of the Indian schools of New Brunswick, and moreover, it always compared favorably with the Public Schools of the province, which was the assertion made by visitors at my school.

I also wish to remind you that I was not only teacher and missionary to the Indian children, but also a Domestic Science teacher—doing equally as much work in that capacity, as the teachers who received an extra remuneration for this work. I also did to a certain extent, the work of a nurse—looking after the milk, Cod Liver Oil, the cleaning of their teeth and Toothbrush Drills, seeing that their faces, hand and nails were clean, as also that their hair was combed and clean.

Now that you have deprived me of my means of livelihood in times of such great depression, I trust, therefore, that you will take into consideration my petition, and will remedy the great wrong done me, and grant me the request which I earnestly implore.

Yours very truly,

Mary T. Hughes.
Ottawa, December 3rd, 1934.

Madam,

With reference to your letter of the 28th ultimo, I beg to say that, as you were informed in official letter of July 6th, last, there is no superannuation provided for teachers of Indian day schools.

Under present regulations, the only payment this Department can make to you is two months' retiring gratuity. A cheque for $150., as gratuity, has already been forwarded to you.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Miss Mary T. Hughes,
North Devon, N. B.
MEMORANDUM

December 11, 1934

DR. MCGILL

Re: Application of Miss Mary T. Hughes, North Devon, NB., for pension

With the return of the attached correspondence from Miss Mary T. Hughes, of North Devon, N.B., will you please submit a draft reply to Honourable R.B. Hanson for the Minister's signature.

George Buskard
Private Secretary.

Ottawa, Dec. 12, 1934

Mr. [signature]

Please report on attached letter and return it to the office of the Deputy Superintendent General.

Do not file.
Ottawa, December 13, 1934.

My dear Colleague:

With reference to the communication which you received from Miss Mary T. Hughes, North Devon, N. B., requesting that she be granted a yearly pension for her lengthy services as teacher in an Indian day school, I would say that no provision is made for superannuation or pension to teachers of Indian day schools. They do not contribute to the superannuation fund. These employees are not considered permanent civil servants and therefore do not come under the Superannuation Act.

In the case of teachers like Miss Hughes, who have taught many years in Indian schools, it is a matter of regret that a pension cannot be allowed. All that could be done in her case was the granting of two months' retiring gratuity, which was paid.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Honourable R. B. Hanson,
Minister, Trade & Commerce,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, August 14th, 1924.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of New Brunswick, has recommended that Miss Mary Hughes be re-appointed as teacher of the St. Mary's Indian Day School for the next school year. The Department has approved of her appointment for another year. The salary allowed her will be at the same rate as she was formerly paid, viz., $600 for the ten teaching months in the year, supplemented by the bonus provided by law.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

B. J. Griffiths, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N.B.

I beg to return herewith the contract for the erection of the school building on the St. Mary's Indian Reserve in order that the person who witnessed your signature may sign. Agreement made in duplicate the day of May A.D. 1912.

Between His Majesty King George the Fifth, represented by the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs of Canada (hereinafter called the Superintendent General);

And Judson Barker of the city of Fredericton in the province of New Brunswick (hereinafter called the Contractor).

The Contractor for himself, his heirs, executors, administrators and assigns, agrees to do in the most workmanlike manner all works and provide all the materials of the best kind shown in the drawings and described in the specifications marked "A" and "B" respectively and signed by the Contractor, and to complete, furnish and hand over to the Superintendent General or to some person by him appointed for that purpose, the frame school-house to be erected on the St. Mary's Indian Reserve near Fredericton, N.B.

and all other work and labour incidental to and necessary for the entire completion thereof, whether specified or shown in the drawings or specifications or not, by the day of September A.D. 1912.

AND in consideration of the above agreement on the part of the Contractor, the Superintendent General hereby agrees to pay the said Contractor the sum of three thousand two hundred and eighty-seven dollars, provided always that the Superintendent General may, at any time during the progress or after the completion or alleged completion of the work, appoint an Architect, Engineer or other officer, in which case the certificate of such Architect, Engineer or other officer, that the work is duly completed and of the amount, if any due, to the Contractor, after making such allowances for penalties and for defective or incomplete work, or for extras and deviations as the Architect, Engineer or other officer shall think fair, shall be a condition precedent to any claim by the Contractor under this contract.

AND the Contractor for himself, his executors, administrators and assigns, further covenants and agrees:

1. That the wages to be paid in the execution of this contract shall be those generally accepted as current in each trade for competent workmen in the district where the work is carried on. If this condition is violated, the Superintendent General may cancel the contract and refuse to accept any work done thereunder.

2. That if the Contractor fails at any time to pay any account for any goods or materials supplied, or money advanced by anyone to the said Contractor for the purposes of this agreement, or to pay the account of any sub-contractor for any work or materials done or supplied for the said works to be constructed under this agreement, and such
account is in either of such cases one month overdue, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such account, and if a week elapse and the same be not paid in full, the Superintendent General may pay such account and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

3. That if the Contractor fails at any time in paying salaries or wages of any person employed by him upon or in respect of the said work, or any of them, and any part of such salary is one month in arrear, or if there be due to any such person one month's wages or salary, the Superintendent General may notify the Contractor to pay such salary or wages, and if two days elapse and the same be not paid in full up to date of payment, or to such other date as may be in accordance with the terms of employment of such person, then the Superintendent General may pay to such person his salary or wages from any date to any date and to any amount which may be payable, and may charge the same to the Contractor, and the Contractor covenants with the Superintendent General to repay at once any and every sum so paid.

4. That pursuant to the Statute in that behalf, this Agreement is made subject to the express condition that no member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of this Agreement or any benefit to arise therefrom.

5. That the Contractor shall not assign, transfer or set over this contract or any interest therein to any person or persons whomsoever, without the consent, in writing, of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs first had and obtained.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the said Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, acting as aforesaid, and the said Judson Barker have hereunto set their hands and seals the day and year first above mentioned.

Signed, Sealed and Delivered

in the presence of

Judson Barker

On July 3rd the Department wrote Clarence W. A letter has come to hand from Mr. O. S. Crocket, M.P., in which he states that his understanding was that an inspector was to be appointed to inspect this work in the same way as inspectors who had been appointed by the Public Works and other Departments of the Government, to watch the work constantly at a daily wage and that he recommended Mr. Brown with this expectation. The Schools Branch has no knowledge of this understanding, if any, and the sum of $50.00 was arrived at by computing at 1/4 on the cost of the building. It is not the practice of the Department on these small works to have an inspector constantly on the job, as, by so doing, the cost of inspection would be altogether out of proportion to the value of the work.

It is usual to allow $5.00 a day with actual expenses.
penses, but it is understood that Mr. Brown lives very close to the reserve and each visit would not necessarily, therefore, take up a whole day. For this reason a lump sum was offered. Sir,

I have consulted with the contractor Mr. Barker and the inspector Mr. Love about the draining of the St. Mary's School and we recommend the following system of drainage.

There is an old drain that comes from the land on upper side of the road and it runs through the cellar about ten inches above the floor. We did not know about this drain until the cellar was dug. The first item in the estimate provides for this drain we want to connect with that drain and run 116 feet to a gulch that runs across the school lot at the very lower or the river end next to the river. The second item provides for draining the cellar the pipe to run 130 feet into the same gulch. The depth of the drain would be about four feet for a distance of about one hundred feet the other thirty feet would not average more than two feet.

We recommend the double drain because we think in the spring when the water is high the drain that runs under the floor would be likely to be full. According to instructions received in your letter of December 21st No. 118345-5.

I have taken over the new school on the St. Mary's Reserve. It was not finished on Saturday the 28th and I did not take it over till Saturday the 4th of January, when Mr. Hudson Barker removed the seats from the old school house and fasten them in place in the new building. Monday being a Catholic Holy day the school was opened on Tuesday the 7th January. There were 24 children present at the opening 14 girls and 10 boys, there is 24 children on role at the present time. The teacher is very much pleased with the new school, and it adds very much to the appearance of the Reserve. The new school building is a very pleasant and comfortable building, and I believe it has been built according to plans and specifications, excepting the blackboard which has been delayed by the railway, it was shipped 3 weeks ago. The contractor has supplied a temporary one until the permanent one arrives, which will be put in place at once.

Ottawa, September 20, 1932.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 15th instant, and, in reply, have to inform you that you may arrange for the supplying of milk for each of the four Indian day schools in your Agency as follows:

- Oroscoto - 6 Qts. per school day,
- St. Marys - 6 "
- Kingsclear - 6 "
- Woodstock - 6 "

This milk may be supplied from the period beginning November 1st, next, until April 1st, following.

The cost of the milk delivered should be, if possible, eight cents per quart, and must not exceed ten cents per quart.

The teacher should keep an accurate account of the quantity of milk supplied each day. This list should be handed to you at the end of each month, and you should prepare a voucher, in triplicate, for the amount due and forward same to the Department, with the list attached showing the quantity of milk delivered at each school. A separate account should be forwarded covering the cost of the milk supplied each school.

The teacher should see that the milk is received in clean containers and that it is kept in a sanitary condition, also that the full quantity received is used by the pupils each day, without waste.

Your obedient servant,

Fredericton.

July 27th, 1933.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department, I have not received authority to clean the Indian School's in my Agency, except the Kingsclear School. Usually the Rev. Father Ryan recommends this work be done, and the Department authorize's me to get the work done. The roof of the St. Mary's Indian School is leaking. I would recommend this roof be repaired, the cost will be small.

I would also recommend the walls and woodwork of the Woodstock, Oromocto, and St. Mary's Indian Schools be washed and the floors oiled, the desks be washed and if necessary, varnished. There would also be a very small amount of repairs, which can be done at a very small cost.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, August 1, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the cleaning of the walls and woodwork, the oiling of the floors, etc., at the St. Mary's, Woodstock and Oromocto Indian Day Schools and regarding the repairing of the roof of the St. Mary's School.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange to have the floors at each of these schools thoroughly scrubbed and the woodwork washed. We will have no funds to oil the floors or to varnish desks. You may have the roof of the St. Mary's School repaired. It is noted that the cost of having this done is small. Any minor repairs required at the other schools can also be carried out. You should see that all this work is completed before the schools re-open.

Please forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred at each of the schools, separately.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

B. J. Griffiths, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N. B.
Fredericton.
August 5th, 1933.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department, the furnace in the St. Mary's Indian Day School, is in bad condition. The fire pot is cracked in several places, the air grate at the top of the inside is burned out, and the grates are also gone. I had a plumber look this furnace over, and I also examined it. The pipes are of galvanized iron and are in good condition, but I cannot see how it is possible to repair the furnace.

A new wood furnace would cost approximately one hundred and twenty dollars. I would recommend a wood furnace if the Department decide to purchase one.

Also the vent pipes attached to the two toilets in the cellar are rusted and leaking. The total cost to repair these would be five dollars. I would recommend this expenditure.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, August 12, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, reporting on the condition of the furnace at present in use at the St. Mary's Indian Day School and recommending, as it is beyond repair, that a new wood burning furnace be installed, at a cost of approximately $120.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase and installation of a wood furnace, of the type and capacity considered necessary for the heating of the building. The purchase should be made from a firm on the approved list. It is noted that the pipes, which are of galvanized iron, are in good condition and can be utilized in connection with the new furnace. You may arrange, also, to have the necessary repairs made to the vent pipes attached to the two toilets in the basement, at a cost of approximately $5.00.

I enclose encumbrance certificate, authorizing the expenditure required in the purchase and installation of the furnace. It is considered that this should include sufficient funds to repair the toilets. After the work has been completed, please forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred for the purchase of the furnace and its installation and also for the repairs to the toilets. You should state on each copy of your vouchers that the expenditure was incurred under authority of E. R. No. 850.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Enclosure

B. J. Griffiths, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N. B.

May 9th, 1935

Sir:

I beg to enclose bills from J. R. Montieth for soap supplied the St. Mary's Indian School. There is a charge of $.35 for Dustbane. There is a lot of mud around this school in the spring and fall, and the children carry it into the school on their feet. This makes a great deal of dust when the Janitor sweeps, and Dustbane stops all this.

I hope the Department approves of my action in getting this.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Fredericton May 15th 1935

Sir

Sir I beg to recommend an expenditure of four Dollars and fifty cents cents to purchase eighty feet of rope for two swings for the St Mary's Indian School. I can get a special price on this rope; the posts which will be needed can be supplied from the New Reserve. The Indians will supply the labour free; the only cost will be the rope. The teacher is very anxious to have these two swings—one for the small children and one for the larger ones. I hope the Department will approve of this expenditure in the fall; the rope can be removed and stored in the school or the Agent can take charge of it.

Your obedient servant,

B.J. Griffiths

Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs

Ottawa
Ottawa, May 22nd, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, requesting authority to incur an expenditure of $4.50 in the purchase of 50' of rope for two swings at the St. Mary's Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that, provided you are of opinion that there would be no danger of accident to the pupils in using the swings, the Department would approve of your supplying the quantity of rope required. It is noted that this will be the only cost involved in installing the swings.

Please forward an account, in triplicate, covering the cost of the rope, which you should attach to a proper voucher form, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

It is noted that, in the Fall, the rope will be removed from the swings and stored in the school, and will be available for further use.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Sir,

Dear Sir:

At your request I inspected the Closet Tanks in the "Devon Indian Day School" and found that both of these tanks were giving trouble. We repaired one, so that it should give satisfaction, but, the other one we find is gone beyond repair, several parts being broken.

I would recommend a new Closet Tank to take the place of this obsolete one. This tank installed would cost Fifteen ($15.00) Dollars.

Trusting this information will be satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

Albert J. Gunter,
per. R. McCullough.

Dear Sir:

May I have authority to purchase and install two new locks on the doors in the Devon Indian Day School?

Dear Sir:

Referring to our invoice for $5.40, for school at Oromoct reserve, $3.60 of this has been paid, leaving a balance of $1.80.

On July 23, 1935, 1 M shingles, $3.60, were delivered on order of Mr. Griffiths, the former agent, and we sent in invoices to him covering this. The next day, however, he ordered another 2 M shingles, amounting to $1.80, and asked us to make out a new set of invoices covering both charges. Evidently he forwarded the first set of invoices instead of destroying them, and also forwarded the invoices covering both charges. On August 31, we received a check for $3.60, invoice for July 23.

We enclose invoices covering the following:

March 11, 1935 - Lbr, etc., for old well, Devon reserve - $1.02
Dec. 28-29-31, 1934 - lbr. etc., for Michael Paul workshop -$17.90

We might say we previously sent in invoices covering all these charges, to Mr. Griffiths, but have never had returns for them. We would appreciate it very much if you can get these straightened out with the Department.

Yours truly,

DEVON LUMBER COMPANY LTD.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find a letter from the Devon Lumber Co.

I might say all these accounts were handed to me the first of the month by Mr. Griffiths and of course I had no way of knowing whether they had been paid or not.

The account for $18.92 which the Company refer to in their letter I have vouchered for No. 95.

The amount of $3.60 for shingles for Oromocto School has been paid, but there is a balance due this Company of $2.79 from 1933, plus $1.80 for shingles purchased by Mr. Griffiths July 23 and 24th, 1935 for the Oromocto Indian School.

This will leave a balance due the Devon Lumber Co. of $4.59, this amount I have vouchered for,

Trusting this explains this matter, I am

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A Indian Agent
Ottawa, November 22, 1935.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, submitting voucher for $4.59 in favour of the Devon Lumber Company.

With reference to the account of $2.79, I beg to say that this was paid by cheque No. 17416 for $2.85 ($2.79 plus 6¢ tax). This cheque was issued and sent to the Company on October 4, 1933. The former Indian Agent, Mr. B. J. Griffiths, was so informed in official letter dated April 25, 1934.

I have been unable to find that the amount of $1.80 has been previously paid, and this item is being passed for payment.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. L. McCutcheon, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N.B.

Dear Sir,

"During the past winter, I was asked to supply the Indian School at Devon, N. B., with milk and the teacher at that school said the milk was most satisfactory.

December 18th, 1935.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I am in receipt of your memorandum of the 11th instant, with reference to Mrs. McElligott, teacher of the St. Mary's Indian Day School, North Devon, N. B.

It is noted you have been informed that she is doing good work, but the reports received by the Department are quite different and, therefore, I feel it advisable to give you full information regarding Mrs. McElligott's services at the school mentioned.

Miss Mary T. Hughes was, for several years, in charge of the St. Mary's Indian Day School but, owing to unsatisfactory service, the Department found it necessary to dismiss her at the end of June, 1934. When it was suggested that Mrs. McElligott might be engaged, the Department communicated with the Inspector of Indian Schools for New Brunswick, Rev. F. C. Ryan, and he replied as follows in a letter dated May 3rd, 1934:

"Mrs. McElligott is only a second class teacher. Again, she graduated in 1896 or 1896; some thirty-eight years ago, and, in this respect, would be little or no improvement on Miss Hughes. She must be nearly sixty-five. Her age is against her. Our idea is to place a good first class teacher, one with five or six years' experience. We want some life infused into this school. This is the very reason why we feel Miss Hughes is no longer required."

Later, the Department was directed to appoint Mrs. McElligott and she began duties on September 1st, 1934.

For your information, I enclose copy of letter received from Rev. W. M. Donahoe, also copy of Inspector Ryan's report regarding his visit to the school on September 24th, 1934, and a copy of his report in connection with his inspection of the school on September 24th, 1935.

Reverend Father Ryan has been Inspector of Indian Schools in New Brunswick for many years and, as a result of his efforts, the work done in our schools in that province has shown considerable progress. After carefully considering Father Ryan's two reports, copies of which are attached, the Department believes it would be in the best interests of this school to dispense with Mrs. McElligott's services at the end of the present academic year, viz., June 30th, next, and engage a younger qualified teacher, who can be secured for the same salary as is being paid Mrs. McElligott.

HAROLD W. MCGILL

Deputy Superintendent General.
MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill,

Regarding the representations made to the Minister on behalf of Mrs. R. McElligott, teacher of the St. Mary's Indian Day School at North Devon, York Co., N.B., I attach hereto copy of a memorandum to the Honourable the Superintendent General dated December 13th, last, which sets forth the facts regarding Mrs. McElligott's teaching services.

Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Schools for New Brunswick, in a report on his inspection of this school on the 15th instant, states as follows regarding Mrs. McElligott's teaching services:

"I am far from being satisfied with this school. The Indian Department should understand as well as I, that a teacher who gives her age to me as fifty-five years is too old to bring about that realized success that the teachers of today's training may better give. It is not fair to the Indians to load a case of charity on them at such a terrible price of sacrifice. I have suggested in the past that this school be supplied with a First Class Superior teacher, younger in years, with the latest training. Some pupils did fair work. I found about all bright and most anxious to study, showing if they had a competent teacher what might be expected."

Father Ryan has nominated the teachers for the schools in New Brunswick during the past number of years and is anxious that all teachers engaged in the Province have First Class Certificates.

Father Ryan recommends the appointment of Miss Ruth E. Murphy, Sunny Corner, N.B., Miss Murphy is twenty-one years of age, and possesses a First and Superior Class License from the provincial normal school.

Fredericton, N.B., Jan. 6, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit report of Indian Agency, N.B. Southwestern for the month of December 1938.

St Mary's Reserve, Devon.

The school closing of the Indian school in this reserve consisted of a programme of twenty-one numbers. After the singing of "O Canada", Christmas carols, hymns and other songs were given. The blackboard drawings and other decorations were very attractive. I addressed the pupils and parents and presented prizes to Gabriel Dedham with a perfect record in attendance and academic subjects, grade eight. I trust that it will be possible to assist this boy in entering the Fredericton High School next year. Other winners were Joseph Paul with a perfect attendance, Grade 5; Joyce Sappier, Grade 4 with perfect attendance and high standing; Grade 3 Lena Meuse and grade 2 Roger Paul and Grade 1 Howard Paul.

A Christmas tree was much enjoyed feature of the closing. Each pupil receiving candy and fruit from Santa Claus.

R. L. MacCutcheon,
Indian Agent.

Fredericton, N. B.,
July 11, 1939.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

Attention Mr. Phelan.

Dear Sir,-

I beg to ask for $150.00 for painting the exterior of the St. Mary's Indian Day School. Two Indians and one white man to be employed. This will include the purchase of paint and brushes and the paying of labour.

May I suggest if this job is undertaken any other way it will cost approximately $100.00 more?

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent
R. Lee MacGutcheon.
Ottawa,
July 28, 1939.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant I will advise you as soon as possible regarding the name and address of the painter who is to be engaged to do the painting at the St. Mary's Indian day school.

If the material costs over $50.00 you should let me have full details regarding what is required as purchase will have to be made through our Purchasing Branch. Present regulations do not permit our forwarding an advance to cover the cost of both labour and material. As soon as I hear from you I will be in a position to decide how much money should be forwarded to you for labour.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

R. Lee MacCutcheon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N. B.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

I have your letter of June 20, File No. 56-4-6 regarding recommendation of Inspector Ryan re-cleaning of the St. Mary's Indian Day School.

Mr. Phelan, Chief of the Training Division will recall that on his visit to me, I pointed out the need of having the interior of this school painted but as funds were limited, the exterior was painted and the inside just cleaned.

If it is at all possible, the interior should not only be washed, but painted; however, under the existing circumstances, this may not be possible. To have the interior thoroughly cleaned, it will cost in the vicinity of 25 dollars. I will employ Indians to do the work.

Reference your last paragraph, regarding the Domestic Science Department of this school. I have definitely informed the teacher, that the Department expects her to look after this part of the work better during the coming year.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent

Dear Sir:

Since making a fire in the furnace in the St. Mary's Indian Day School, I find that the clean-out pan in the chimney has completely rotted away, and must be replaced with a new one. Dear Sir;

In regard to our telephone conversation re pasteurized milk for Indian Day School, St. Mary's Reserve, Devon, N.B., will say that there has never been any question of pasteurizing milk for this School. For one reason there is no law in New Brunswick to compel anyone to sell pasteurized milk and another is that up to the present year there hasn't been a pasteurizing plant here in Devon.

As a fully qualified graduate nurse, I realise more than most people the danger of contaminated milk, and for this reason condemned the cans in use and wished bottles substituted. The can was rusty and could not be properly sterilized.

We have a herd of pure-bred Jerseys, which was started when our first child arrived, so that we should have the best quality milk available for our children. It is this same high quality that we have supplied to the Indian School. This same quality milk in Ontario, then sold under the Jersey Trade Mark bring a higher price than any grade of pasteurized milk, and would be called Certified Milk. It also has a much higher food value than pasteurized milk.

Hoping that this is a satisfactory reason and explanation why the milk is not pasteurized, I remain,

Very truly yours,

Dear Dr. MacMillan:

The Indian Affairs Branch has been supplying milk to children in the Indian Day School, St. Mary's Reserve, Devon, N.B.

Memorandum:

The Deputy Minister.

Re: Milk Supply, St. Mary's Indian Day School.

This Branch is quite prepared to accept the statement which Mr. Leo F. Hayes, Devon, has already made to the Department that his milk is of the best quality.

That fact, however, would not prevent it from being the medium which would convey tuberculosis, undulant fever, typhoid fever, diphtheria, scarlet fever, or any other pathogenic bacteria which might either be in the milk itself, or carried by persons handling the milk.

It is considered that the only safe treatment for milk is to pasteurize it, which means raising the temperature of the milk to 146° F. and keeping it at that temperature for thirty minutes. It has been found that this procedure will kill all pathogenic bacteria ordinarily found in milk.

It is true that the province of New Brunswick does not enforce compulsory pasteurization, but the Department of the Federal Government responsible for the health of its Indian wards should set a lead in this matter and insist upon pasteurized milk wherever it is available.

The following letter, which the Acting Superintendent of Medical Services received from the Chief Medical Officer for the Province of New Brunswick, supports this view:

The Secretary,

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

St. Mary's Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

The porch of this school is in need of repairs as the frost during the winter lifted the foundations of the posts and carried them sideways as well as upwards.

In doing this the roof was started from the main building (school) and the sides pulled apart.

In order to make the proper repairs, the porch will have to be jacked up and a new foundation built for the posts. It would not be wise to repair this porch on the same foundation, for if done this way, it would have to be done yearly.

A hole should be dug in the ground and a cement foundation in one large piece at the bottom, and tapering towards the top which would serve as the bottom step of the porch, would be the proper and permanent way to make these repairs.

Mr. Tom Nash, a half-breed who lives on the St. Mary's Reserve said he could make the required repairs for about $20.00; that would include the material required as well as the work.

Mr. Nash has followed this line of work for a number of years and has the name of being a good workman by the people of Devon.

I would request that authority be given to have this porch repaired by Mr. Nash at a cost not exceeding $20.00

Your obedient Servant,

Edward Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:-

With further reference to our conversations regarding a bill for water rates for the St. Mary's Indian Day School and Reserves, I will have to inform you that I am still looking for an account.

Would you please make another effort to have these bills made up and forwarded. Dear Sir:

During the night of October 31st some damage was done to the St. Mary's Indian Day School, also the swings on the school grounds.

This Halloween prank, as it may have been intended for, was committed after midnight as the Devon Policeman, Leo Hayes was asked to keep watch on the school property when patrolling in that area and he stated that he did not see anything unusual and nothing touched, but he noticed several Indians, young men, hanging around the junction of the Devon Road and the one leading to the New Reserve. He was busy for some time arresting a drunk and when he returned the Indians had gone but he felt sure they were the ones that damaged the school property.

I made enquiries around the Old Reserve and was told by Tom Nash that Mark Brooks, as one of a party that had knocked down a piece of his garden fence and he came nearly getting hold of Brooks but when he started to follow the mob, they put the rocks to him, as he expressed it, and he had to return to shelter.

Miss Sharkey, a woman who lives adjacent to the school property on the south side of the road says she heard the swings at the school full so she got up and looked out of her bedroom window and saw a number of boys running towards the river on the Old Reserve. (She did not know if they were Indians or not.)

I felt sure the Indians were guilty of this crime, so on Monday I went to Isaac Paul, the Assistant Chief, who is Acting Chief, and told him what had happened and said I knew some of the boys and asked him to talk to them when they returned from work that night.

I told him I had hired Tom Nash to fix the property again and if the boys who were all or nearly all, working, would pay for those repairs, I would treat the matter as a Halloween prank and let it drop, otherwise I would hand it over the R. C. M. P.

Mr. Paul was unwilling at first and said it was not the Indians, then said if it was, it would not cost them much and he would talk to them and get a settlement.

During the early evening, I went to the reserve but was told by Mr. Paul that the boys or young men of the reserve were not guilty and would not pay for the damages.
I turned the matter over to the R.C.M.P., but they could not seem to get any information which would be of value in finding the guilty party or parties.

The damage done was as follows:

1. Tore steps away from side door.
2. Tore down one of the posts holding up Porch.
3. Tore down swings which were put up at the expense of the Department.
4. Broke two panes of glass in cellar windows.

Cost of new glass, putty, nails and repairing damage $5.00.

Your obedient Servant,

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
From interviews it is evident that no information would be obtained from any of the Indians. They are either very clannish or are afraid to inform on each other. Contacts were made at the reserve and should any information come to light this Det. will be notified and further investigation will be made.

STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION

The Officer Commanding,
Fredericton Sub-Division,

Forwarded for your information:
This matter was reported to me on the 4th inst. by the Indian Agent, H.J. Whalen. The Agent Mr. Whalen carried out an investigation before handing the matter over to us. His investigation consisted mostly of telling the persons mentioned in this report, that if they all got together and paid the amount of the damage, no action would be taken. When it appeared this would have no effect he handed the matter over to us. It would appear that this space of time gave the Indians considered ample time to discuss the matter and plan their denial. From that it has been my experience that it is practically impossible to induce one Indian to inform on another. This investigation will be continued and every effort made to get something definite that would assist us in bringing the case to a successful conclusion.

(Fredericton Detachment Case)

5-11-42

1. On this date a complaint was received from Edward J. WHALEN, Indian Agent, to the effect that the steps on the school-house, on St. Mary's Indian Reserve, in Devon, N.B., were damaged during the night of October 31st, and November 1st (Halloween night). The extent of the damage was to the amount of $8.00.

2. On instructions from the H.S.O., I/C Fredericton detachment and accompanied by Sgt. Trapp, a patrol was made to Devon, N.B., where the Devon Town Constable, Leo HAYES, was interviewed. From him was learned that between 11 p.m. and 1 a.m. on that night several Indian boys were around town and on Bridge Street. In this crowd were Mark BROOKS, Teddy BROOKS, Charles PAUL, Harold RAPINER and William BROOKS. Mr. HAYES did not see the boys around the school.

3. Tom HAM, who lives near the school was interviewed. He stated that after mid-night of October he heard some in his yard. He went out and saw several boys in the yard. He gave chase and he recognized Mark BROOKS and Charles PAUL. At this time the two boys mentioned ran through an alley towards Bridge Street.

4. Teddy BROOKS, who lives right by the school was interviewed and questioned at length. He admitted being with the boys during the early part of the evening and claimed that they went to the New Reserve with William BROOKS at about midnight, after that he came right home and went to bed. He denied any knowledge of who damaged the school-house steps.

5. William BROOKS was interviewed and his story did not differ from that of Teddy BROOKS.

6. Mark BROOKS, Charles PAUL and Harold RAPINER were all interviewed and questioned at length. They all admitted of being around town during the period until about 1 p.m. of November 1st, but they denied being at Tom HAM's place and of having anything to do with the school. From questioning the boys it is quite obvious that they had discussed the matter, their stories are all the same and it would appear that they are going to stick to it.

5-11-42

7. Information was received that Peter ROBERTS, who has a shack near the school was around his shack during the night in question and that he may be able to supply some information. On being interviewed he said that he went to his place during the night, but saw no one around. He said that he saw the boys in question in Fredericton during the night. It would not be easy that he saw the boys on the old reserve. It was learned from Tom HAM that Peter told him he saw the boys near Tom's place, but Peter ROBERTS denied this.

1. Further to report submitted on the above on the 3-11-42 nothing has been learned in this connection. Steve Nash who lives on the Old Reserve and who is reliable was interviewed and nothing could be gained from him.

2. The above damage was done on the night of October 31st, 1942 and enquiries were made by the Indian Agent, Mr. J. Whalen immediately. Not being able to get any information he asked this Detachment to investigate. During the investigation Mark Brooks, Teddy Brooks, Charles Pauls, Harold Smith and others were questioned and all were interviewed, but with negative results. All of the men mentioned were in and around the old Reserve during the night but no one was found who saw them near the school house. The main suspects are Mark Brooks, Charles Pauls and Harold Smith. From interviews and after being questioned they all denied being near the school or having any knowledge of who did the damage.

3. It is evident that between the time the damage was done and the time the investigation was carried on, the men in question had time to agree on definite story about their whereabouts and they all stick to it. From experience it has been found that one Indian will not inform on another. There does not appear to be any way of getting any information on this case and the fact that the suspected parties have decided to stick to one story I would request that this case be closed as Further Investigation Unwarranted.

The O.C. "J" Div. (Sgd.) P.P. Pavlovich, Sgt.

I wish to refer to your letter of July 26, regarding the painting of the Woodstock Indian School.

I found it impossible to get anyone to paint this school, although I had one painter who promised to do it and then disappointed me.

At last, Tom Nash, the man who painted the St. Marys school, agreed to go to Woodstock with me and to give the walls and ceiling one coat of paint. This he did with the help of a man, Ed Gallagher, for five hours.

The interior of this school should have another coat and the entry and subbase should be painted as well. We have nearly enough paint to do this and Mr. Nash would go up again if authorized to do so.

The labour and material for painting the Woodstock and St. Marys schools were kept pretty well within the amount allowed although the Woodstock school received less labour and material than that of St. Marys.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

Re: Saint Mary's School.

A board fence which is about 6 feet high and built across the back of the school yard is in need of repair. Part of it blew down during the spring, and although I tried to have it fixed up temporarily, I could not locate any dry lumber for the purpose. I considered it would only be wasting money to use green lumber, as it would twist and check when exposed to the sun.

At the present time, a number of mills are sawing lumber in this vicinity. The lumber required could be purchased and dried in a short time for this work.

In order to do a good job, posts will have to be reset, and a quantity (about 200 running feet) of 2 by 4 will be required to repair the fence, also a quantity of nails and spikes. To do a finished job, the fence should be painted.

The total cost including labour will be in the vicinity of $75.00.

Could authority be granted to do this work during the summer holidays?

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
June 21, 1944.

Mr. E.J. Whalen, Indian Agent, Fredericton, N.B.

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $75 to cover the cost of material and labour in repairing the fence at the St. Mary's Day School.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Fredericton, N.B.,
June 16, 1944.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

Re: Saint Mary's School.

There is no flagstaff at Saint Mary's Indian School. The teacher, Mrs. McElligott, told me a pole had been obtained previous to my appointment as Indian Agent, but before being erected, it disappeared. The teacher would like to have a flagstaff as she has a flag.

I could not get an exact estimate on this work, but Tom Nash, a half-breed living on the Indian Reserve, says he thinks he can get a pole, peel, paint, and erect it for about $35.00. He does not say he can do it for this amount however.

May I have authority to get a pole and have the same erected?

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
June 22, 1944.

Mr. E.J. Whalen, Indian Agent, Fredericton, N.B.

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, you may arrange for a flag pole for the St. Mary's School. The cost mentioned in your letter seems high and it would be appreciated if you could have a flag pole erected for a smaller amount.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

I attach account amounting to $77.45 covering the cost of materials purchased for repairing the basement of the St. Mary's Indian Day School in order to provide a room for domestic science.

It was decided to employ Sisters at this school from January 1, 1945, and the Agent has strongly recommended a change in the building in order to provide a domestic science room. Labour is scarce in this section of New Brunswick, but workmen were available early in January and local purchase of the materials was authorized in order not to delay the improvements.

It would be appreciated if you would issue purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding is as follows: - 283-76-10-691.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Encl.
Saint Mary's Indian Day School,
Devon, N. B.
Feb. 24th., 1945.

Mr. P. Phalen,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phalen:

As you know we are now well established in our school, to which has been added the Domestic Science room, and already we feel we that we have accomplished much. It is now painted and in order, and the work of the pupils is very satisfactory to date.

If you could only visit it, we are sure you would agree with us in our reporting that being a basement room, the lighting is not sufficient, so knowing from the past your understanding and kindly sympathy, I feel no hesitation in approaching you with a request to have the building wired and suitable lighting installed.

I spoke to Mr. Whalen about it, and though he realizes it is necessary, as he was criticized for putting the lights in the Woodstock school does not wish to make any move in the matter, until he receives word to do so.

He has already exceeded his quota, due to high price of labor at the present time, and much was needed to put the department into proper condition. We did our best to keep expenses down, by doing the painting and practically all of the cleaning ourselves.

Word has just come that our requisitions will be arriving soon—another cause for rejoicing.
I almost forgot another fact. Our sewing machine is not, and cannot be put into working order, and we really need one badly. At present, I have been able to borrow one for a few weeks, but of course I am anxious to have one for ourselves. For awhile, when we were painting etc., we thought we might even fix the machine, but it was impossible. Even the experienced machinist we had look at it could do nothing, so that is our second request, a sewing machine. The loom, we hope, soon to be ready also.

We may surprise you too, by telling you that we are building up a nice little Library for the school, through the generosity of friends.

Perhaps sometime, when peace is again restored we may have the pleasure of welcoming you to our little school.

With thanks for all past favors, and anticipating a favorable reply.

I am,

yours most sincerely

Sister Marietta
Ottawa, March 2, 1945.

Dear Sister Marietta:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo and am pleased to know that matters are proceeding satisfactorily at the St. Mary's Indian Day School.

It has not been our general practice to install electricity in Indian day schools. However, I will discuss your request with the Acting Director, and if it is felt advisable to make any change from our previous policy you will be advised.

I look forward to having the pleasure of visiting your school at some time in the future.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. Sister Marietta,
St. Mary's Indian Day School,
Devon, N. B.

Dear Mrs. Whalen,

Do you think that it would be possible to procure new desks and seats (single ones) for the school? The present double ones are most inconvenient, as many of them are too small for the pupils. If only we could get single ones of various heights, that is, small, medium, and large, it would certainly be a great advantage, and also a benefit to the health of the children.

I know you and also all the members of the Department are always most solicitous for the advantage of the children and for the betterment of the school, so this I feel will prove to be. Trusting that you may feel disposed to petition the Department for this requisition.

I am,
Your most sincerely,

Sister Jean Marie.
Fredericton, N.B.
March 30, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Enclosed you will find a letter which I received from Sister Jean Marie, Teacher at the Saint Mary's Indian School.

The desks referred to by the Sister are old double ones and much too small for the larger pupils, who have to bend over and consequently crowd their lungs.

I am submitting this letter for your comments and will not forward a requisition for new seats until instructed to as I know much has been spent on this school during the past year.

Edward G. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 3, 1945.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Indian Agent,
Fredericton, N. B.

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo, with reference to supplying new desks at the St. Mary's Indian Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I think this could be done at comparatively low cost, as the N.B. Power Co. is located directly opposite the school.

The heating of the Domestic Science room is problem number 11. When the furnace room was converted into a class room, it was necessary, in order to stand erect, to remove many of the hot air pipes, and this in turn reduced the heating of the room to a very great extent. Our only means of heating this room now is a very small stove, and in winter this is not at all sufficient.

I wonder, Mr. Hoey if you remember the type of heater that was sent to the Domestic Science room at Tobique a few years ago, and if it is possible procure another similar for Saint Mary's. I am sure Mr. MacPhail, The Indian Agent of Tobique Reserve would be glad to give you any information you might require re. type and size of this heater. When it was installed our heating difficulties were over. We also found it to be a great fuel saving. Now that Army Camps are closing it should be an easy matter to obtain an item of this kind.

When we came to this school last January we found it very poorly supplied with books and other teaching essentials. We were obliged to requisition books and supplies for immediate use in order to make a beginning.

Now at the end of six months we have a better knowledge of the whole situation, and we find we still need books and materials if we are to get our classes off to a good start in Sept. The pupils are very bright, and are applying themselves to their studies, and located as they are so near our great Educational centers it would be too bad to keep them back.

The Reverend Superior of our convent here has been most generous and has done everything in her power to help equip the school, and stimulate the interest of the pupils. She has purchased for our use, an organ, sewing machine, and a set of tables and chairs for the Domestic Science room.

On Easter Monday we held a sale work, a great deal of which was done by the children. The proceeds have been used to improve the class room. We purchased covering for the floor, and paid to have it laid. We also paid two men for two days labor in and around the building. Not knowing the conditions at the beginning you would hardly realize the extensive repairs that were necessary.

Sister Electa was in the city for the closing exercises of U.N.F. and while here she visited our school, and was very much pleased. Her interest in the welfare of the Indians is just as keen today as when she labored among them.

Recently we have had many visiting officials from the schools in the city and elsewhere, and all have expressed great surprise at the high standards of this school.

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

For the past six months I have been teaching the Indians at Saint Mary's School, Devon. My duties here are along the same lines as at Tobique, handicrafts, and general instruction in all forms of Home-making.

When our Indian Agent took us to visit the school for the first time and when he pointed out to me a corner of a much dilapidated furnace room as my future class room, I must say, I viewed the whole situation with utter discouragement.

However, thanks to the assistance given by the Dept. and the extreme generosity of our Community, much has been done since that day in early January to make the little school a bright and cheery place to work in, and it is only under such conditions that we may hope to bring out the best that is in the pupils.

I may say that much the same problems are apparent here as in other Indian Schools. Our greatest difficulty right now is the lack of any lighting system whatever. I feel it is unnecessary for me to go into detail about the necessity of lights in a basement classroom which is two thirds underground.

And it is in this room that Grade 1 and II work for four or five hours every day. And here also the other Grades are at different periods, taught, weaving, sewing, knitting and other fine arts. It is hardly fair to the pupils to be obliged to work under such difficulties, and terrific eye-strain will in a very short time be the dire result.

The light in the class room upstairs too, is not adequate for dark days in early winter, even now on rainy days, and this spring, by far the greater number of days have been dull and rainy, consequently the pupils are working under a strain almost constantly. I am sure such conditions existing in a class room where about forty children spend the school year would be totally condemned by any medical authority.

Now from an educational view-point. We have at our disposal a very fine moving picture machine, and it is possible to procure at all times an excellent line of both educational and entertainment films free of charge. I have found motion pictures a great advantage in the class room. They seem to wean the children from the habit of frequenting theatres, where very often, the type of picture shown has a demoralizing effect on the young and impressionable mind. I know, Mr. Hoey, that this consideration alone will induce you to have lights installed in St. Mary's this summer.

With reference to your letter of June 20, 1945 in which you ask what it would cost to install electric lights in the basement room of the Saint Mary's Indian Bay School, I wish to state that if the whole of the rooms were not wired the Sister would be unable to show pictures or have evening classes as I believe she is planning on having with the older girls during the coming year. I have a tender from Gerald LaPlante, a man who lives very near the school and he said he could wire the building any time I gave him the instructions to. He is a good man I am told and is at the present time wiring a new addition to the C.P.R. station. Fredericton, N.B.

You will notice that his tender is $68.00 for the wiring less the lamps. As this was without a plug outlet to the school room I called him and asked what the extra would be and he said $3.00. Thus satisfactory wiring less the lamps would be $71.00. I asked Staples, Electricians, what they would charge for wiring the school as required and they said in the vicinity of $100.00 therefore I did not get a tender from them.

Mr. Gerald LePlante, North Devon, N. B., has completed the wiring of the Saint Mary's Indian Day School according to his tender submitted July 14, 1945.

There is a city By Law (city of Fredericton) which states that Mr. H. J. Moore, city electrician, must inspect the wiring of any building and he is to be reimbursed by the contractor or person who does the work.

I took Mr. Moore to this School after the work had been done and he said everything was in order. He did say, however, that the main School Room should have at least four lights and better still six, rather than two as Mr. LaPlante's tender called for. Mr. LePlante, however, has carried out his work according to his tender and placed one plug outlet in the School Room and costs $3.00 extra as stated in my letter of July 17, 1945.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Re: Purchase Order 4328

Referring to the above order, it is regretted that there have been unexpected delays in completing this initial order for your requirements. However, by letter of October 2nd, 1945 from the warden, I am now informed that production has been well started and the contract will be completed by the end of December, 1945. I inquired of the Warden regarding part delivery before that, but his reply explains that the manufacture of these desks is a production-line job and the manufacture of each component part proceeds in turn to the final assembly.

It is pointed out by the Penitentiary Chief Trade Instructor that it was necessary to manufacture and design gauges, jigs and fixtures within the Penitentiary and after the men engaged in the manufacturing operations have become more acquainted with their task faster progress can be expected.

I am sending a copy of this letter to the Purchasing Agent of your Department as well for his information and trust that the delay in delivery has not upset your plans to a major extent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re Voucher No 297 - Canadian Cottons Ltd., Marysville.

The above numbered voucher in favor of Canadian Cottons Ltd. amounted to $15.60 while their bill was $17.25. The difference of $1.65 was to be paid in cash but through an oversight the envelope containing the money remained in the office until today. (See receipt attached).

I was informed from the office of this firm that they had written to the Indian Affairs Branch regarding the $1.65, as they thought a mistake was made in the amount of the cheque.

It is regretted the oversight caused extra work for all parties concerned.

Edward J. Whalen,

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 12th instant dealing with the desks which have been ordered by the Branch from the St. Vincent de Paul Penitentiary and in this connection to advise that I have visited St. Vincent in the course of this week and inspected the desks as requested.

These desks were all finished with the exception of a few who had received their final coat of paint. The desks are of very sturdy construction and very well finished. There is no doubt that they will be satisfactory.

They will be shipped to Indian Agent Whalen on Monday next, April 22nd.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.
The Chief
Training Division
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
OTTAWA, Ont.

Attention: Mr. Philip PHELAN

Dear Sir:

Re: Your File 56-4-5
Re: Purchase Order No. 4328
40 Single Chair Desks

Replying to your letter of March 20, 1946, and subsequent arrangements by telephone, the Warden of St. Vincent de Paul Penitentiary has reported that Agent Brisbois inspected the new desks on April 12, and expressed his satisfaction with the job. Undoubtedly he has reported to you in this respect. It was pointed out to him by the penitentiary officials that in view of this being an initial order, they would be glad to receive suggestions as to improvement after the desks have been in use for some time in order that these could be incorporated in later orders.

The delay in completing this first order is a source of regret both to the penitentiary and to this office, but you will doubtless appreciate that difficulties would be encountered which would not be present when dealing with future orders. Therefore, I bespeak your cooperation in the allotment of future orders for this article. Preferably, plans should be made well in advance in the event that materials are still in short supply due to the steel situation in the United States.

I wish to thank you for the opportunity and cooperation displayed by your office in enabling the penitentiary to develop this new article of manufacture for the Government Service.

Yours very truly,

G.L. SAUVANT, Inspector
Acting Superintendent.
Fredericton, N. B.

Indian Affairs Branch, Deptt. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 23/46, asking for a requisition for coal or wood required at the Day Schools in my Agency for the coming school year.

I am forwarding this requisition as requested, but Sister Mariette, who teaches grades one and two in the basement of the St. Mary's Indian School and also has Domestic Science classes there, is very anxious to have nearly all the basement for that work and has asked if fuel oil could not be used in the school rather than wood, as the wood used in the furnace has been stored in the basement in past years and this with the furnace takes up over half of the space.

The cost of the oil burner installed in the furnace according to quotations from the Irving Oil Company is $575.00. This includes a 200 gallon tank and complete installing. The oil costs 11½¢ a gallon.

The basement at the present time has a number of hot and cold pipes running through it and if the school room is to be enlarged with satisfactory results, these pipes would have to be removed. This could be done by changing over to a pipeless furnace.

May I hear from you regarding this change.

Edward Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, May 10, 1946.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Indian Agent,
Fredericton, New Brunswick,

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to installing an oil burner in the furnace at the St. Mary's Indian Day School. Please let me have more definite information regarding the type, size and, if possible, the catalogue number of the burner on which you have received a quotation from the Irving Oil Company.

Instead of using oil, would you favour using coal? It might be possible to change the grates in the present furnace and coal would take up less space than wood. I would like to hear further from you before making a definite decision.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
St. Vincent De Paul Penitentiary

August 3, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa,

I wish to refer to your letter of June 3, regarding the converting of the furnace at the St. Mary's Indian School into a pipeless furnace.

Mr. Frank Flannagan, who is an expert in that line of work, promised to check the furnace and tell me if this could be done.

It was not until yesterday, however, that he did this, and informed me the furnace could be converted into a pipeless furnace at a cost of approximately $50.00. If this work is done, and the pipes removed in the basement, Sister Marietta wishes to have a Domestic Science room, which is also used for the grade 1, enlarged. In fact, her ambition is to build another room in the basement for grade 1 and have the present room used entirely for Domestic Science work.

It would cost approximately $300.00 for the labour and materials to complete the room.

Sister Marietta informed me that she would rather have the room complete and burn wood for the coming winter in the furnace, than to have the old burner installed and not have the additional room, but if finances were available, she thought it much better to install the oil burner as well. As the wood would have to be left out of doors and only two or three days supply put in at a time.

If this work is to be done, it should be commenced at once.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 12, 1946.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Indian Agent,
Fredericton, New Brunswick.

With reference to your letter of the 3rd instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $50.00 for converting the furnace at the St. Mary's Indian Day School.

You may also arrange for completing the room in the basement. If necessary, an expenditure of $300.00 for material and labour is approved, but this amount appears high.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re: Single Chair Desks

Ottawa, 13 September 1946.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant with reference to placing further orders for school desks.

I regret that it is not possible at the present time to give you any estimate of our future requirements of school desks.

Owing to increased attendance, we have had several requests in the past few months for extra desks and one of these orders was placed with you on June 28th. Only eleven desks were ordered at that time but in a letter dated the 11th instant, we are advised that they have not yet reached the School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

Re: Your File 56-4-5
(W.T. 1)
Re: Manufacture of School Desks - St.Vincent de Paul Penitentiary

Replying to your letter of September 13, 1946, the Warden of St.Vincent de Paul Penitentiary has reported that he expects the 11 desks ordered on Contract #12098 will be delivered in approximately two weeks. The delay was occasioned by non-delivery of angle iron needed for manufacture.

In the matter of desk orders, I wish to draw to your attention our letter of April 30, 1946, in which your cooperation was solicited in anticipating future orders. The present policy of the Government will not allow this Branch to proceed to manufacture in advance a line of articles unless the receiving department can give an assurance that the article will be taken after completion. If this Branch had had this assurance, we could have proceeded to purchase materials last April and had the desks ready for delivery when required at the beginning of the school year.

The following is a note, which Inspector Titus wrote in the register at the St. Mary's Indian Day School:

"The new furniture has added much to the appearance of the room and will without doubt, contribute towards better posture on the part of the pupils. The additions to the library are greatly appreciated also. I would suggest a new hulonlate blackboard (green) for the side wall as the present board is not good, and is too far from the floor. I would also suggest a school radio to take advantage of Maritime School Broadcasts."

In addition to this the Sisters have asked for the following: A piano for the advantage of the school and particularly the children taking musical examinations. They would also like to have 12 new desks, similar to the ones supplied last year, as there are that many extra children to start in the year 1947-48. Also a second teachers desk, as Sister Arietta has the children of the smaller grades in the basement. They are also anxious to have a drinking fountain and lastly, to have an oil burner placed in the furnace for another year.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
