Memorandum:

Mr. Agent Farrell writing under date of the 3rd inst., suggests the advisability of securing the services of one or two of the Public School Inspectors of New Brunswick to visit, examine and report upon the course of instruction, discipline and methods employed by the teachers in our Indian schools in that Province.

In this connection I beg to say that as far back as the year 1890 communication was opened up through the Secretary of State with the local Governments of the older provinces with a view to utilizing the services of the Public School Inspectors to make such visits and inspections as those suggested by Mr. Agent Farrell. All the local Governments with the exception of New Brunswick fell in with this proposition and we are now receiving semi-annual reports from these inspectors and paying for such visits.

The attention of the Lieutenant Governor of New Brunswick was from time to time called to the omission of the Public School Inspectors of that Province to make the reports called for by this Department, but, up to 1891, we had not succeeded in obtaining any reports and after that date the matter was dropped.

In view of the failure on the part of the Provincial Government of New Brunswick to take any notice of the request made by this Department to secure the services of its inspectors, I do not know whether you would feel inclined to re-open negotiations to this end.

The outlay attendant upon the services rendered by the Public School Inspectors comes to about $1000.00 a year and little, if any, good is derived from the inspectors' visits. However, it may be considered that this money is well
well spent in the public interest, as it indicates the desire of the Department to have its schools conducted along the lines of the provincial public schools.

I prepared a memorandum on this subject in June, 1895, which was submitted by the then Deputy Superintendent General to the Minister, setting forth the expense incurred and what I considered the poor return obtained for the expenditure. The Minister, however, did not feel disposed to disturb the existing arrangement without consulting Council in the matter. I am unable to obtain the original memorandum at present but a copy is placed herewith.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

On April 30, last, Miss Annetta Bradley applied through Mr. Agent Farrell for an increase in salary as teacher of the Tobique school, and the Agent was informed that the Department regretted that it had no funds available for the purpose.

Although she has not since renewed her application, the Public School Inspector in his report on this school, dated the 25th ult., states as follows:

"Miss Bradley is conducting this school with marked success. The pupils are greatly interested in their work, the order and attendance are excellent and it gives me much pleasure to state that I have never seen the school in a better condition than it is at present. Miss Bradley's salary should be raised, as I am quite sure her services cannot be retained much longer unless she receives some financial inducement to remain. I believe that her withdrawal would be a serious loss to the Indian school at Tobique Point."

Miss Bradley is the holder of a second-class certificate and previous to taking charge of this school had six years' experience. She also has a certificate in Nature Study and School Gardening from the Macdonald Institute.
Institute, Guelph, and has made good use of her experience in this line, and the Inspector says that the school garden work greatly interests the Indians children and is a special advantage to them in many ways.

Sir,

In the Regulations for the Education of Indian children clauses 1 to 7 provide for the compulsory attendance at school of all children between the ages of six and fifteen, except under certain conditions clearly set forth.

The Indians on the Tobique Reserve have now a fine school house, well equipped, and a teacher of more than ordinary qualifications and ability. The Department is also providing means to teach sewing in the school.

In view of these conditions all the Indian children should be sent regularly to school, but it would appear that some of the parents are indifferent and do not take advantage of the excellent facilities provided to educate their children. The Department has, therefore, under consideration the question of putting the regulations in force on this Reserve. The first step will be the appointment of a Truant Officer and it has been suggested that the Constable combine these with his other duties.

You will be good enough to discuss this matter with the Indian Council and ascertain upon what terms the Constable would be willing to undertake this work.

I am sending you under separate cover four copies of the regulations.

Your obedient servant,

I offer little department cards and redeem them with other cards when they get twenty. Also try to show them the value of regular attendance, and get parents interested.

I generally offer a prize for attendance.

In my experience in this Indian school I find that I can accomplish more by offering a reward and holding out an incentive in the way of a prize, than in any other way. No matter how trifling the reward they will work for it. If it were not for the expense I should like to be able to give a reward for those pupils who attend every day each month without any absent or tardy marks. Tardiness is a great fault in this school. I tried keeping and having them write tardy. But this term I am trying the giving of a half of a half-holiday to those present and not tardy for two weeks. I find this way is much better.

In reply to your letter No. 18387/1 of March 25th, in which you referred to my annual report on the Tobique School, in which I recommended a reward for attendance, and in which you asked for nature of award & cost. Would say that I should like to give something in the form of a book, booklet or picture (to little ones) to those who had perfect attendance & punctuality. I should judge it would cost perhaps from $1.50 to $2.00 according to perfection of attendance, for they'd find resort to anything much quicker when a reward is offered.

Regarding the money and pending answers when I can get little books etc., much cheaper than I can here. That is the way I do with getting the cards. Send to firms which deal in them. How they do enjoy getting that credit. Good merit card although it means only one twentieth part of a picture card, and in this way we have all given short care & out-houses carefully attended to promptly without cost.

I hope you will note in my return the good attendance of the boys at my school.

The two book which you sent me for prizes which reached me too late for making the People of the Plains. Were given as awards at the end of the March Quarter.
The two pupils whom I considered as the most deserving of them were:

Peter Tremblay aged 14 yrs Grade II
Gabriel Perley aged 11

These two pupils were never tardy, missed nothing of their own fault—only being the two boys who serve assist the parish priest in the services of the church hall to be absent from school. Peter Tremblay two mornings and Gabriel Perley three mornings but as soon as they were free came at once to school. In school they are very diligent and take great interest in their work and their conduct is above reproach.

Another boy John Devore aged 14 yrs Grade III having never missed a day in the three years I have taught—here I feel I deserved a reward, but the books sold were rather deep for him. So I gave him a Bible History which I had.

I sincerely hope the Dept will take an active interest in these three young boys and encourage them in their education. For they are very, very good boys and I feel they would make something good.

I wish it were possible for the Dept to pave their way clear to place them in some decent boarding school and educate them so that evil company or some other companions might not spoil them. Then when they grow...
As they I feel would exert a great influence for good in the rest of their race. I should like very much to see the experiment tried.

I should like to call the attention of the Dept. to the matter of school material ordered.

When here before all things asked how my requisitions were sent and in the best manner. This year something is omitted each time and the material seems of a very inferior quality not what I ask for at all. Why so this?

I was much surprised to find that the Dept. refused to send me the water-colors and Cabinet of Weights & Measures. If they knew the difficulty in teaching Indian children a thing which could not be demonstrated to them while teaching it. I am sure they should never have refused to send it. As these weights & measures are very necessary part of a practical education.

I also asked Dept. to kindly send me a picture of our modern King Queen. But I think they must have overlooked the matter, as never heard if you were willing to do so or not.

Dear Mr. Michaud,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant enclosing a letter addressed to you by Miss Bradley, late teacher of the Tobique Indian School, in reference to the amount of salary paid her for her services during the current school year.

In reply I beg to say that the salary appropriated for this school is $400.00 per annum. The school year commences after the summer holidays and ends on June 30th of each year. Miss Bradley completed a year on June 30th last, and received her full salary of $400.00. During the current year she taught 59 days.

In computing salaries for broken periods this Department makes payment in the proportion that the number of days taught bears to the total number of teaching days in the year, which is 216. This is manifestly an equitable method of computation in such cases. Miss Bradley was, therefore, paid 59/216 of $400.00 or $109.36.

MOROCCAN TREATY SIGNED.

The Moroccan war cloud was dispelled finally when the long-discussed treaty between France and Germany on the subject was signed. This treaty grants France all her demands; it concedes to her a predominant influence in the whole of Morocco. All that Germany gets for her interference is a vast armament worth tens of millions of Lads Chaim and a naval stronghold on the Congo, to give her a port on that river. She will retire from Agadir, the Moroccan port which she seized in order to force France to divide up. The French Premier, Caillier, in a recent statement declares that the time has come when Africa can no longer be closed to civilization by barbarism. The idea of "Morocco for the Moroccans" will no longer do, he says, for Morocco is so near Europe that peace and order must be maintained there. Traders of other nations will be protected, but France will hereafter have a free hand among the Moors.

Luckily the wars in Tripoli and China cropped up to occupy attention, else the humiliating bargain which Germany made with France over securing the Morocco road would have caused much more trouble than it has. Even now it has made lots of bad feeling in Germany, for it is felt that the government backed down before English threats. A bit of a row was going on in the Reichstag (German Parliament) over the matter. Herr Bebel the Socialist leader demanded that this and all treaties should be submitted for approval. The rejection to the right hon. Conservative Leader Heydebrand, known as the "Uncrowned King of Prussia," was very bitter toward England; German would be found ready, said he, to make sacrifices of fortune and life in order to fight this enemy. "The German people will give a German answer to this English question," he asserted. Crown Prince Frederick William was present during the discussion and gave encouragement to the critics of his father's government. It is reported that Emperor William was very angry when he heard of this and rebuked the future emperor-to-be with unmistakable severity.

THE ITALO-TURKISH WAR.

Reliable news of the Italo-Turkish war is meager, the diplomats doing everything that it is obvious that most of them are made up out of whole cloth in the newspaper offices. Correspondents who have told the situation too graphically have been expelled from Tripoli by the Italian authorities. The Turks and the Italians are incensed at the criticisms that have been made against their government for seizing Tripoli and they deny the charges of cruelty made against the Turks. Military operations seem to be going on around Tripoli and the neighboring ports, but nothing decisive. The Italians are said to use a fleet of balloons for scout purposes in locating the enemy. The Arabs, however, believe that the Turks are crafty, where they regard with superstitions fear. There is small chance that any of the powers will mix in the war, in spite of the great sentimental sympathy. The practice is not to intervene in such cases unless both sides ask for a peacemaker. Turkey has called for intervention, but Italy would spurn it.

THE MAINE LIQUOR LAW.

For over forty years the State of Maine had a prohibitory liquor law. The liquor interests brought on a contest to repeal the law. For a long time the results were in doubt. Alternately Maine was said to be dry and said to be then wet. Finally the government made a recount and the state is officially proclaimed dry by a majority of 758.

ACROSS THE CONTINENT IN AN AIR SHIP.

The wonderful tales in the "Arabian Nights" are being outdone every day by the marvelous achievements of modern science. The aeroplane flight of Gullbreth P Rodgers across the continent from New York City to Pasadena in California is the latest of these modern miracles. Our grandfathers, even our fathers, twenty years ago would have laughed the prediction of such an achievement out of the realm of remote possibilities.

Starting from Sheepshead Bay race-track, Long Island, New York, on September 17, Mr. Rodgers reached Pasadena, a suburb of Los Angeles, on November 5, having traveled a distance of 3,290 miles in forty-nine days. The best previous record was set by Mr. Hubert H. Aldred's flight of 1,265 miles from St. Louis to New York. (See Canadian Teacher, page 154.) Rodger's success was wrested by courage and perseverance from a long series of failures. At the beginning of his second day's flight his Wright machine crashed into a tree, and four days later it broke two propeller-blades in a collision with a horse-drawn ferry. A string of troubles followed and mishaps worried him across half a dozen States. But he came through his adventures practically uninjured, although, according to a Pasadena correspondent, "His airplane has been eaten and repaired so many times that only the vertical rudder and the dripping-pan remain of the original outfit with which he started."

Five years ago the Wright Brothers were the only men in the world who could fly heavier-than-air machines. In the fall of 1906 they pointed with pride to the fact that they had been up in the air 160 times and had covered altogether exactly 1,000 miles, or an average of a mile each flight; but they had one wonderful record of being up for over four hours and covering twenty-four miles.

And now we have just been aviator Rodgers complete his journey of over 3,100 miles from New York to Los Angeles, in less than six weeks, and a total flying-time of about three days.

HILDA'S CHRISTMAS.

Standing apart from the childish throng,
Little Hilda was silent and sad;
She could not join in the happy song,
She could not echo the voices glad.

"What can I do on Christmas day?
I am so little and we are so poor."
She sat alone here in the corner.
"I wish there never was a Christmas more."

"Mother is sick, and father can't know
How children talk of their gifts and joy,
Or he'd surely try, he loves me so,
To get me just one single toy."

"But Christmas is not for you to get,"
She said, with a voice tender and low.
"It's for what you give," said wee Janet,
And the words made Hilda's heart rejoice.

"It isn't our birthday," went on the mite,
"It is Christ's, you know; and I think He'd say
If He were to talk to us to-night,
That He'd wish us to keep it His own way."

A plan came into Hilda's head;
It seemed to her she could hardly wait;
"I can't give nice things," she bravely said,
"But I'll do what I can to celebrate.

"I can give the baby a day of fun;
I can take my plant to the poor, lame boy;
I can do something for the old folks' home;
And the old kite I can mend for Roy.

"I can read to father and save his eyes;
I can feed the birds in the locust grove;
I can give the squirrels a fine surprise,
And grandma shall have a letter of love."

Now when the work was done and done,
And Hilda cried to bed—
She forgot that she had no gift of her own—
"What a lovely Christmas it was!" she said.

THE SPELL.

I hang a string of verse
Against my cabin wall;
What think you, was the fortune
They prayed might me befall?

Not fame, nor health, nor riches,
To tarry at my door,
But that my old, old sweetheart
Might visit me once more.

Out of the mated day-dream
Among the boiling fires
They prayed she might remember
The lover that was hers.

They prayed the gates of silence
A moment might unclose,
The hour before the hill-crest
Is flushed with solemn rose.

O prayers of mortal longing,
What latch can ye undo?
What comers once departed
Ever returned for you?

All day with tranquil spirit
I kept my cabin door
In wonder at the beauties
I had not seen before.

I slept the dreamless slumber
Of happiness again;
And when I woke the thrushes
Were singing in the rain.

—Bliss Carman.

A wind came up out of the sea,

It hailed the ships and cried, "Sail on,

The night drags by; and the breakers die

What if it were her lover?

A CHRISTMAS TREE.

... Straight in the middle of the room, cramped in the freedom of its growth by no encircling walls or moon-reached ceiling, a shadowy tree arises; and looking up into the dreamy brightness of its top I lose myself in visions of Christmas recollections. "That bark! The Watts are playing, and they break my childish sleep! What images do I associate with the Christmas music, as I see them set forth on the Christmas Tree? Known before all the others, keeping far apart from all the others, they
gather round my little bed." An angel speaking to a group of shepherds in a field; some travelers, with eyes uplifted, following a star; a baby in a manger. Child sleeping among sheep; a child with grave features, a solemn Figure, with a mild and beautiful face, raising a dead girl by the hand; again, near a city gate, calling back the son of a widow, on his bier, to life; a cross, with a locket hanging from an open ring of a chamber where He sits, and letting down a sick person on a bed, with ropes; the same, in a tempest, walking on the water to a ship; again, on a sea shore, standing in great multitudes; again, with a child upon His knees, and other children round; again, resting sight to the blind, speech to the dumb, hearing to the deaf, health to the sick, strength to the weak, and help to the ignorant; again, dying upon a cross, watched by armed soldiers, a thick darkness coming on, the earth beginning to shake, and only voices heard, crying out for them, for they do not what they do there. A moment's pause, O vanishing tree, of which the lower boughs are dark to me as yet, and let me look once more! I know them, and although I have no mother whereupon I have loved have love and smiled; from which they are departed. But far above, I see the Raiser of the dead girl and the widow's son; and God is good! Oh, may I, with a gray head, turn a child's heart to that Figure yet, and a child's trustfulness and confidence.

ANTECEDENTS OF PRONOUNS.

As you have already learned, the antecedent of a pronoun is the word or words for which the pronoun stands.

As the form of the pronoun depends frequently upon the form or use of its antecedent, it becomes important to recognize as readily as possible the antecedent of each pronoun.

1. The antecedent may be either a noun or a pronoun; as

These boys who were late may remain.

Those who came early may be excused.

(a) The antecedent, as the word indicates, is generally placed before the pronoun; but it may be placed after the pronoun, as in the sentence:

1. John, saw these things.

2. Who went with you?

The antecedent of "they" in 1 is known to the speaker and perhaps to the hearer, but it is not expressed.

The antecedent of "who" in 2 is found only in the answer.

(a) Sometimes the antecedent consists of two or more words connected by a conjunction, as in the following sentences:

1. John and James took their sister with them.

2. It was Mary or her sister Jane who was ill.

The subject "John and James" is the antecedent of "their" in 1, and the complement "Mary or her sister Jane" is the antecedent of "who" in 2. In what number is each of these antecedents?

Note carefully the antecedents of personal pronouns, especially when they are separated from their pronouns by several words, as in the sentences:

1. One of the men who were sent lost his way.

2. Let each of the girls take her own book.

3. A man's manners frequently show his bringing up.

The antecedent of "his" in 1 is "one"; of "her" in 2 is "each"; of "him" in 3 is "man's."

**Gender of Pronouns**

(a) The gender of pronouns, like that of nouns, is determined both by their form and by their use. Thus the gender of "he," "his," "him," "she," "her," and "it" is unchangeable; but the gender of other pronouns can be known only by their use in sentences; as, for example,

1. The man whose horse has returned.

2. I answered the letter which came yesterday.

3. These are the girls that did so well.

4. The ladies who were present removed their hats.

Who in 1 is masculine, because it refers to boy. Which in 2 is in what gender, and why? Give the gender of the italicized pronouns in 3 and 4. If you change the meaning of any of these nouns, shall we be obliged to change the pronouns?

(c) When the gender of the antecedent is not known the pronoun relating to it is masculine. For example, in the sentence "The owner of this cat could not find his cat," the pronoun "his" is represented by the masculine pronoun "his."

But some words like "baby," "animal," "fish," etc., which include both males and females are represented by the neuter pronoun "it" or "its," etc.

The baby is crying for its food.

They chained the dog because it was cross.

(d) When the antecedent consists of nouns of different gender, corresponding pronouns should be used, as:

Every boy and every girl must sign his or her name.

See an awkward use of the pronouns may be avoided by changing the sentence to:

All the boys and girls must sign their names.

1. The following notes may assist you in the use of the demonstrative and indefinite pronouns.

(a) "This," "that," "these," "those," "every," and "each" refer to the singular number.

(b) "Either" and "neither" refer to one of two persons or things, and are therefore singular. Thus in speaking of two persons we say,

Neither of the two brothers earned his own living.

(c) "None" may be used in both numbers, as:

There is none (no one) that doth good, no, not one.

(d) "Few," "many," "these," "those," and "several" are used only in the plural number.

(e) "Some" when it refers to quantity is singular; but when it refers to number it is plural. Thus we should say, "Some of the flour was wasted," and "Some of the books were torn."

The pronouns "all" and "any" are also used in this way.

All of the boys were found.

Not any of the boys were found.

All of the money was found.

Not any of the money was found.

(f) "Former," "latter," "first," "last," and "same" may refer to singular or plural substantives and therefore may be in either number, as

I was the first to arrive.

We were the first to arrive.

The first settlers of New England were Pilgrims and Puritans; the former were Separatists, the latter were not.

Mr. Smith and his brother were pupils of mine; the former was always good in his studies, but the latter was somewhat slow.

It was they that I saw before.

They were the same that I saw before.

For this reason, if we do not know the number of a noun in its form, we have only to ascertain the number of its pronoun. What is the number of "who" in each of the following sentences?

4. Mistakes are frequently made in the use of pronouns whose antecedents are collective nouns or indefinite pronouns, especially when the pronouns are used without nouns closely connected. For example, in the sentence "Neither of my brothers brought his books," the indefinite pronoun "neither" is singular and therefore requires "has" and not "have" to agree with it.

In the sentence "The Board of Aldermen adjourned its session at ten o'clock," the collective noun "Board" is used in the singular and therefore requires the pronoun "its" to be used.

But in the sentence "The Board of Aldermen were divided in their opinion," "its" and not "its" is used, because the antecedent, "Board" is used in the plural.

A pronoun agrees with its antecedent in person, number, and gender.

A finder is made by cutting two pieces of cardboard, as shown in Fig. 1. When placed together, as shown, they serve as a frame for the sketch. **REPRODUCTION STORY**

THE BLIND MAN AND THE LAME MAN.

A very rich man was to give, in a few days, a great feast. It was to last all day. A blind man and a lame man wanted to go to the feast.

The lame man was very lame, and he could not walk so far. The blind man was big and strong, but he did not know the way.

The blind man came to the lame man and said: "We must both go to the feast. You know the way there; I do not know the way. I will carry you. You must be the head and eyes, and I will be the body and legs."

"Very good!" said the lame man. "I want to go very much. You are very kind to carry me. If you will be the body and legs, I will be the head and eyes, and we can both go."

The blind man took the lame man upon his back, and in this way they both went to the feast, and had a fine time.

MOROCCAN TREATY SIGNED.

The Moroccan war cloud was dispelled finally when the long-discussed treaty between France and Germany on the subject was adopted. This treaty grants France all her demands; it concedes to her a predominant influence in the whole of Morocco. All the German claims for interference is a very small wedge of territory north of Lake Chad and a small frontage on the Congo, to give her a port on that river. She will remain from Agadzé to Nouadibou, which she sought in order to force France to divide her share. French Premier Caillaux in a public statement declares that the time has come when Africa can no longer be closed to civilization by barbarism. The idea of "Moors for the Moors" will not do, he says, for Morocco is so near Europe that peace and order must be maintained there. Traders of other nations will be protected, but France will hereafter have a free hand among the Moors.

Luckily the wars in Tripoli and China cropped up to occupy attention, else the humiliating bargain which Germany made with France over cutting off Morocco from war would have caused much more trouble than it has. Even now it has lots of bad feeling in Germany, for it is felt that the government backed down before English threats. A big rumpus was raised in the reichstag (German parliament) by Socialists like Herr Bebel the Socialist leader demanded that this and all treaties should be submitted for approval or rejection to the reichstag. Conservative Leader Heydebrand, known as the "Unrowned King of Prussia," was very bitter toward England; Germans would be found ready, said he, to make sacrifices of fortune and life in order to fight this enemy. "The German will give a German answer to this English question," he asserted. Crown Prince Frederick William was present during the stormy session and that evening wrote to the critics of his father's government. It is reported that Emperor William was very angry when he heard of this and rebuked the future emperor-to-be with unmistakable severity.

THE ITALO-TURKISH WAR.

Reliable news of the Italo-Turkish war is meager. The dispatches are so conflicting that it is obvious that most of them are made up out of whole cloth, in foreign telegraph offices. Correspondents who have told the situation too graphically have been expelled from Tripoli by the Italian authorities. The Italians in Italy and abroad are very hot at the criticisms that have been made against their government for failing in Tripoli; they deny the charges of cruelty made against their soldiers. More or less fighting seems to be going on around Tripoli and the neighboring places, but nothing extensive. The Italians are said to be effect of balloons for reconnoitering, locating the enemy, and the Arabs are much exercised over these craft, which they regard with superstitious fear. There is small chance that any intervention will mix the matter, in spite of the international peace treaty. The practice is not to intervene in such cases unless both sides ask for a peacemaker. Turkey has called for intervention, but Italy would spurn it.

THE MAINE LIQUOR LAW.

For over forty years the State of Maine has had a prohibitory liquor law. The liquor interests brought on a contest to repeal the law. For a long time the results were in doubt. Alternately Maine was said to be dry and said to be then wet. Finally the government made a re-count and the state is officially proclaimed dry by a majority of 738.

Starting from Sheepshead Bay race-track, Long Island, New York, on September 17, Mr. Rodgers reached Pasadena, a suburb of Los Angeles, on November 5, having traveled a distance of 3,220 miles in forty-nine days. The best previous record for this record was Henry A. Ford's flight of 1,261 miles from St. Louis to New York. (See Canadian Teacher, page 154.) Rodger's success was wrested by courage and perseverance from a long series of mishaps. At the beginning of his second flight his flight machine crashed into a tree, and four days later it broke two propeller-blades in a collision with a barbed-wire fence. A string of minor accidents and mishaps worried him across half a dozen states, but he emerged from adventure practically uninjured, although, according to a Pasadena dispatch, "his machine has been broken and repaired so many times that only the vertical rudder and the dripping condenser of the original outfit were when he started."

Five years ago the Wright Brothers were the only men in the world who could fly in heavier-than-air machines. In the fall of 1906 they pointed with pride to the fact that they had been up in the air more than twenty minutes, together exactly nine miles, or an average of a mile each flight, but there was one wonderful record of being up for over half an hour, and covering twenty-four miles.

And now we have just seen aviator Rodgers complete his journey of over 3,100 miles, from New York to Los Angeles, in less than six weeks, and a total flying-time of about three days.

ACROSS THE CONTINENT IN AN AIR SHIP.

The wonderful tales in the "Arabian Nights" are being outdone every day by the marvellous achievements of modern science. Transatlantic flight of Capt. F. Rodgers across the continent from New York City to Pasadena in California is the latest of these modern miracles. Our grandfathers, even our fathers, twenty years ago would have laughed the prediction of such an achievement out of the realm of remote possibilities.

HILDA'S CHRISTMAS.

Standing apart from the childish throng,
Little Hilda was silent and sad;
She could not join in the happy song,
She could not echo the voices glad.

"What can I do on Christmas day?
I am so little and yet so poor!
She sat alone here in a dreary way:
"I wish there never was a Christmas more."

"Mother is sick, and father can't know
How children talk of their gifts and joy,
Or he'd surely try, he loves me so,
To get me just one single toy."

"But Christmas is not for what you get,"
She heard a small, soft, tender voice,
"It's for what you give," said wee Janet,
And the words made Hilda's heart rejoice.

"It isn't our birthday," went on the mite,
"It is Christ's, you know; and I think He'd say
If He were to talk to us to-night,
That He'd wish us to keep it His own way."

Mr. Pedley,

Miss Ethel F. McGrand, teacher of the Tobique Indian School, has applied for an increase of $50.00 in her salary. She is now in receipt of $450.00 a year, which is the highest salary paid to any Indian school teacher in New Brunswick. She has a good school and is a competent teacher. I at once called, by phone, Miss Feeney of New Market, York Co., and after considerable trouble got her to consent. She will open school on the 9th, 1st.

Before writing you this time, I firmly decided to wait her arrival. She is here, and I do trust she will still be here when my letter reaches you. Teachers are more uncertain than the stock exchange. I find many wait until the last minute, trying to get the best possible wages. It is very difficult to get teachers now to take Ind. schools. I feel that the Dept., in the near future, will be forced to hold out stronger inducements, in order to secure teachers for Ind. Reserves, or do without them.

You have no idea what trouble I had during this vacation, in procuring teachers. However, I think we have good ones. I did my best.

Yours respectfully,

Insp. Of Ind. Schools for N.B.

Sept. 13th, 1920.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Miss Feeney only remained about five days. She is to write you. Boarding conditions in an Indian house did not suit. As I said before, I realise more than ever, the imperative need of "TEACHER'S RESIDENCE" on the Reserve, before we can expect to keep a good teacher.

Miss Bridget Crain has arrived. She will open school tomorrow the 14th. The children will only loose a half-day. She is not a licensed teacher but has covered school to the ninth grade. Her application was approved by the Dept. a few weeks ago, but Miss Murdoch, a licensed teacher, sent in an application two days later, she was also accepted by the Dept., but refused to come at the last moment. Miss Feeney was next called but only remained a few days. Then came Miss Bridget Crain. Time will tell how many yet may follow. All this trouble arises over the want of a proper place for the teacher to board.

I trust the Dept. will do all in their power to rectify these disorders. I understand Miss Isaacs had considerable trouble to get a boarding place at Kingsclear. She was determined to leave; at last, she got in a kind of a place for a while.

I know, if houses of some kind are not provided for teachers at once, that even before the term expires there may be vacant Ind. Schools. I feel sure that next year will certainly find some closed.

Faithfully submitted to your consideration.

I remain,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Inspector of Ind. Schools for N.B.

Memorandum for File.

Rev. Father Hugolin, of the Tobique Reserve, N. B., visited the Department today and was exceedingly pleased to learn that we were providing for a teacher's residence for the Indian day school. In the Supplementary Estimates for the current year there is an item of $1500 for this purpose.

The Rev. Father strongly urges the appointment of two Sisters, one to act as teacher and the other as field matron; and this fact should be kept in mind when the plans for the bungalow are being drawn. I have intimated that we will correspond with the Rev. Father Ryan in this connection and that the salary allowed the Sisters will be at the rate of $550 plus bonus, each. OTTAWA, June 5, 1922.

Reverend Sir,

Reverend Father Hugolin, of the Tobique Reserve, visited the Department a few days ago and strongly urged the appointment of two Sisters, one to act as teacher and the other as field matron on that Reserve. He stated that it was quite likely that the services of these Sisters would be available by September 1, 1923. If the services of the Sisters are secured, it will be necessary to provide proper accommodation for them.

We have this year an item in our Supplementary Estimates for the purpose of providing a small bungalow for a teacher in connection with this school, but, if the Sisters are engaged, more extensive living accommodation will have to be provided than is contained in a bungalow. Father Hugolin also stated that it was the intention of the church authorities to ask for the removal of the school to another site, as the church desired to obtain from the Indians the land on which the school now stands for church purposes. Father Hugolin stated that he would let the Department know in the course of the present summer the definite arrangements that are being made regarding the securing of the teachers and the moving of the school, and when this information is received we will then be in a position to go on with the work of putting up a residence for the Sisters. We intimated to Father Hugolin that we would inform you regarding the above mentioned matters. I might say that if the Sisters are engaged, we would be prepared to allow them a salary at the rate of $550 per annum, plus any bonus provided by law.

Father Hugolin intimated that the present teacher, Miss Nellie Dugan, intends to resign at the end of June. It will, therefore, be necessary to obtain the services of another teacher to succeed her until such time as the services of the Sisters can be obtained. If Miss Dugan resigns, you should endeavour to secure the services of another teacher, and the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher selected by you should be forwarded for the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Schools for New Brunswick, called at the Department today and discussed the question of the employment of the Sisters as teachers at Tobique. He strongly recommended that only English speaking sisters be appointed, and that the English language be taught exclusively in the classrooms. We informed him that any teacher appointed would have to meet with his approval as regards ability, qualifications and the language of instruction in the classroom.
Dear Mr. Scott:

On my late visit to Ottawa, in conversation with Mr. Ferrier, I rather understood him to state that the sisters that should come to Tobique would be required to teach both French & English. If this be the case, I feel in this new departure, that our schools will be so burdened that they will fall away below the standard. At present the VIII & IX Grades did take French. At this period they could successfully do so, but it would be nothing short of a crime to burden those poor little ones with an extra language before they reached the above standards. It is not like in Quebec, the schools are surrounded with French and this is the language there, while here all our Ind. Schools are surrounded by English speaking people and this is the language the poor Indians must use.

I may have misunderstood Mr. Ferrier, yet I would like to have a good understanding in this matter, so when the Tobique sisters come, that I might know just where we stand in this matter. I also wish the Fathers to know our school conditions in this province, and if Quebec has its regulations, we should have the privilege likewise. In having our system respected, in Rome do as Rome does, is a very good doctrine.

Yours respectfully,

Ottawa, January 5th, 1924.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, relative to the domestic science work that is to be performed at the Tobique Indian Day School and on the Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that you should arrange to have one of the Reverend Sisters instruct the older girls at least two hours per week in sewing, knitting, the making of garments and in personal cleanliness and the care of their clothing. It is thought that this instruction could be given by one of the teachers during the regular classroom period. She could arrange the hours at which this would be convenient without interfering unduly with the other classroom work.

If the Sisters have time, and can make arrangements, it may be possible to give the women of the Reserve instruction in sewing and making garments. The Department is, however, not prepared to make any extra arrangement for the teaching of domestic science. If there is any likelihood of the work being of benefit to the Indian women, and if you are sure that they would avail themselves of the opportunity to acquire knowledge of domestic science, the Department might be favourably disposed next year to authorize the enlarging of the work along these lines.

Any materials required for the purpose of teaching sewing, etc., to the pupils, and, to a limited extent, to the Indian women of the Reserve, during the present school year, will be supplied upon a requisition prepared by you and handed to Mr. Agent Roberts for transmission to the Department.

Regarding the preparation of a report showing the work done, it will be satisfactory if the teachers prepare a list of the garments made and a general statement regarding the number who received instruction and any facts of interest, and hand the same to the local Indian Agent together with the quarterly return of attendance. We have no special forms for the purpose.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sister Francois de Sales,
Tobique Indian School,
Saint John, N.B.

Sir:-

Ottawa, October 6, 1925.

Madam:

I have your letter of 30th ultimo addressed to Mr. Sutherland of this Department, stating the arrangements you request you may be allowed to make to provide for the teaching in the classrooms and the teaching of domestic science at the Tobique School.

It is noted that on account of the number of pupils, it will be necessary for two of the Sisters to carry on the classroom work and that one of these Sisters can therefore only devote two hours each week for the teaching of domestic science.

The Department is anxious that as much time as possible be devoted to the teaching of domestic science. It is hoped that you can arrange during the present school year to devote all the time possible to this work. We are aware of the lack of facility for the carrying on of this branch of work, but hope that this important branch will receive the utmost consideration on your part. I will be pleased if you will inform Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Schools of the arrangements you can make for the carrying on of both the classroom work and the teaching of domestic science.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 26, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to that portion of your letter of the 14th ultimo which relates to the qualifications of the teachers at the Tobique Indian Day School. There is evidently a misunderstanding in connection with the Department's wishes. We require professionally qualified teachers, and, if the present incumbents are not satisfactory, steps will be taken upon receipt of a further report from you to arrange for other Sisters. Indian schools are managed, as you know, solely by this Department and therefore do not come under the Provincial Departments of Education. We do not stipulate New Brunswick professional certificates for teachers at New Brunswick Indian schools, but we expect teachers with suitable training and professional qualifications.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to that portion of your letter of the 30th ultimo which is in reply to official 66-2-1 of the 26th idem. I have reviewed my letter and I cannot see that it is either ambiguous or indefinite. Therefore, I am wholly at a loss to understand the tone of your answer.

The words "This Department" undoubtedly refer to Indian Affairs and to our officers in the field, including yourself. I cannot understand why you consider the words "Provincial Departments of Education" include yourself.

Reverend Father:

The Superior of our Convent in Maliseet tells me you are not satisfied with the results of your examinations in the school of that Reserve. I regret it and I hope the situation may still be remedied; we are disposed to do the best we can to meet your views.

We would be very thankful if you could kindly tell us what you think reprovable in our Sisters' method of teaching and would also appreciate any suggestion towards its improvement.

At the time of our engagement for the school at Maliseet, we were informed that the New Brunswick certificate was not required for the teachers, so we concluded that we would not be asked to follow the program of studies of that province. We should have had an understanding with you on that subject. I hope you will forgive us for not having asked your instructions at the very first, but we were under the impression that the school was directly dependent on the Department at Ottawa.

I beg you to believe, Reverend Father, in our sincere desire to give satisfaction in the task undertaken for the welfare of the children on the Reserve.

Pray accept the homage of my respect and bless,

Your humble servant,

(Sgd.) Sr. M. Claire d'Assise, Sup're. Gen'le.

Dear Father Ryan:

I have your personal letter of the 7th instant to Mr. Sutherland and myself, enclosing a communication which you received from the Superior General of the Franciscan Order of Sisters at Tobique regarding the supplying of qualified teachers.

In this connection it is noted that they have no teachers having New Brunswick qualifications, but that they can supply a teacher with a First Class Normal School Certificate from Alberta. The appointment of this teacher as principal of the Tobique school will be satisfactory, and, in order not to inconvenience the Reverend Sisters by making a change at the present time, it is considered that it would be quite satisfactory if the new teacher begins duties on or about September 1st, next. The present teacher could continue for the balance of the school year to June 30th, next. You may make the necessary arrangements with the Superior General to have the teacher referred to by her take charge of Principal at the beginning of the next school year. I say and pray that the Superior General is prepared to make the change in the Principal at any time before the end of the present school year, she may do so, but we will leave this matter in your hands to make the change at any time before September 1st convenient to the Reverend Sisters. When this change takes place and the new teacher having the Alberta qualifications assumes duties, I shall be pleased to hear from you giving the date upon which the change is made.

The services of the present assistant teacher, Sister M. Rita, will be satisfactory, and she may continue in the work.

The letter which you received is returned herewith as requested.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. F. C. Ryan,
Inspector of Indian Schools,

Reverend Father,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant. We are rather surprised to hear you say now that New Brunswick licensed teachers are required for the Tobique school while we were given a contrary assurance when application was made to have our Community accept the post.

You object that the Department pays a licensed teacher salary. It is true, but for all the work which has to be done on the reserve, three sisters only are salaried, while a personnel of six religious is required. However, the salary question is not what we wish to consider presently and it is not in this light that we place ourselves to let you know our following decision:

If you cannot accept the proposed religious - who has taught successfully in the United States and in Montreal - kindly wire us at our expense and we shall undertake the necessary procedure to present our resignation as teachers and nurses on the Tobique Reserve to Right Reverend Bishop Chiasson and the Department.

There is certainly a great deal of good to be done at this post and we are glad to devote ourselves there, but places more advantageous in all respects do not want; we would relinquish the task without regret to religious having the qualifications which you desire.

The time to take other important decisions is limited, that is why we beg you to give us your answer by telegram.

Trusting that you will comply with our request for which I thank you sincerely, I beg you, Reverend Father, to receive the homage of my respect.

Dear Rev. Father:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, re "The Tobique School and The Little Franciscans of Mary."

It is undeniable that teachers must be qualified in order to conduct a school; but it is true also that a teacher's license and especially of such or such a province is not always and is not the only qualification of the teacher's ability. For our Province of N. B. Public Schools a teacher's license is a necessary condition; but, as far as I know, the Indian Dept. at Ottawa does not make it a necessary condition to teach in the Indian schools of N. B. and so persons not holding such N. B. teachers licenses, but teachers' licenses of other provinces or of some of the United States or even with no license at all but otherwise qualified both as to instruction and as to successful experience in teaching may, in my humble opinion, be very good and efficient teachers.

Now, with respect to The Little Franciscans of Mary, I have no personal knowledge of their teaching ability and after having visited the school at Tobique, you will better able to pass judgment on this point. The only thing I know about it is from the Superior General's letters to you and to me, stating that the Sister (Marie Doloris, I think,) has a ten years' experience in successful teaching. For myself, I would accept this as a sufficient qualification. If found on inspection to be correct.

I have no objection to the Sisters of Charity of St. John taking charge of the Tobique School, providing they would at the same time take charge of the hospital there, but I fear they would not get along as well perhaps with the Franciscan Fathers. The Little Franciscans of Mary are a regular tertiary order of St. Francis, and they are more or less under the spiritual guidance of the Fathers. I fear it would not be the same with the Sisters of Charity. There are so many things to consider when it comes to do God's own good work. To speak frankly I would much sooner see things remain as they are at present, providing of course, the work of the school is satisfactory. As for placing a lady teacher at the head of the Advanced Dept., I do not think it would be feasible; the Sisters would hardly accept this arrangement.

I shall await your decision and your answer before writing the Superior General of the Little Franciscans of Mary.

I am very sincerely and respectfully

Yours in Our Lord,

Bishop of Chatham.

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit to Tobique Indian Reserve, N.B.

While at Tobique I visited the day school and watched the work of the teachers. Dear Mr. Scott:

I find that both the Rev. Sisters are working overtime in the classroom and when all pupils return a very hard year lies before them. The Rev. Nurse has now more than she can do under the most trying circumstances and the deplorable conditions in so many of the Indian homes. I can see no other hope for the progress of the work than a field matron. The Department realizes that it is a strict rule of this Order that no Sister goes alone to visit homes. If a field matron or a domestic science teacher was appointed, the Nurse could accompany her on certain days and much good could be done. As it is at present, the teaching of domestic science must suffer, and this would be most disastrous, as we cannot drop this most important branch of our work without detriment to all the other work on the Reserve.

I feel with the Department that already for the size of this Reserve three paid Sisters is considerable. Yet the work must be done. Why not appoint another paid Sister as field matron and domestic science teacher, who, in conjunction with the Nurse, could clean up conditions on the Reserve. This arrangement might be given a trial for three or four years, after which period, no doubt, three Sisters could do the work.

INSPECTION OF TOBIQUE AGENCY

School on Tobique Reserve.

The day school on the Tobique Reserve is conducted by the Sisters in a commodious modern building, fully equipped for all purposes, the two large class rooms being bright and roomy and the whole building kept in a clean, first class condition.

Thirty-two children (19 boys and 13 girls) comprise the pupils in the lower grades 1-4, whilst 15 children (8 boys and 7 girls) form the upper class (grades 5-9).

The actual attendance is fairly satisfactory, although there is a tendency on the part of some of the Indian parents to keep their children at home on occasion, for somewhat trivial reasons, a frequent excuse being that the children have insufficient clothing and shoes, but the Indians were told at a general meeting that the children must attend school regularly except in case of sickness, and that where clothing was really needed, the Indian agent would see that such was provided.

Two boys, Felix Francis & Sam Davis, and five girls, Mary J. Sappier, Madeline Alexander, Susie Paul, Eva Nicholas and Pauline Moulton were found to be often absent, and the truant officer, George Bernard, was instructed to visit the parents and impress on them the necessity of seeing that their children regularly attended school in future.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I am writing you regarding our music proposition in our school. This year we are fortunate to have a Music Teacher who also helps me with the Domestic work. As music plays such an important part in the curriculum of New Brunswick schools I am wondering if you Department will help us to provide the necessary books, instruments, etc., to carry out an efficient music program.

With the aid of the children and through our industry we have procured a piano which is not new but serves the purpose until we are able to do better. In view of this fact we feel the Department should be willing to give us a donation to help provide the rest of the necessaries.

We have about fifteen pupils who are anxious to study music and later we expect to include some of the older children which we feel would be a great help to the morale of the place.

I have spoken of this matter to Mr. MacPhail who is very interested but of course can do very little without the consent of the Department.

Ottawa, August 18th, 1924.

Sir:

I have to inform you that the Department has arranged for the incumbency of Reverend Sisters at the Tobique Indian Day School and Hospital. The Superior General of the Order, of Bay St. Paul, has named the following staff:

- Sister Superior: × Sister Marie-Francois-de-Sales,
- Nurse: × Marie-du-Carmel,
- Field Matron: × Marie-Paul-de-la-Croix,
- Teacher: × Marie-Isidore,
- Asst. Teacher: × Marie-Rita-du-Sacre-Coeur.

Salary will be allowed for each of the three Sisters at the rate of $550 for the ten teaching months, plus the bonus of $150. As in the case of other workers at Indian schools, salary will be paid quarterly, 1/10 for the September quarter and 3/10 for each of the other three quarters. The Department proposes to have one cheque per quarter for salary and one for bonus made out in favour of the Sister Superior.

The Sister Superior is being informed that she should look to you and to Rev. Father Ryan for instruction and advice.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Chas. J. Roberts, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Red Rapids, N.B.
Makineet N.B.

Aug. 25, 1924

To Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Dear Sir:

Immediately after the close of the term on the "Indian Reserve" Council at Ouegna Role and myself were for six weeks directed here at Silver City (Post Office at Makineet) to re-address my mail to Ouegna Role, which he did, but some time in July I received the cheque for $50.00, but not the one for $5.00. I got the cheque for
I've cashed at Perth this week. I was at Maliseet P.O. this morning and the Post Master told me he sent back envelopes to my address, Poveshue Lake Maine. I had other letters sent there which are now being sent back to me which I should have received early in July. Please let me know what I am to do about this affair? And all matters of Maliseet N.B.

Yours Truly

(Mrs) Mary Craig
Ottawa, August 29th, 1924.

Madam:

In reply to your letter of the 22nd instant, I beg to say that a cheque for your bonus was sent to you on July 11th, last, addressed to Maliseet, N.B. This cheque has not been returned to the Department. It appears from your letter that this cheque was forwarded from Maliseet to Presque Isle, Maine, and possibly it will be returned from there. It might be advisable for you to communicate with the Postmaster at that point.

At the present time the Department can do nothing further, but if you do not receive this cheque within the next few weeks you should again advise the Department and indemnity forms will be sent you for signature, in order to enable the department to issue a duplicate cheque.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Mrs. Mary Craig,
Maliseet,
N.B.

Ottawa, November 9, 1928.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, relative to the payment of salary of the Sisters engaged on the Tobique Indian reserve.

In reply I beg to say that salary at the rate of $700 per annum is allowed for each of three Sisters on this reserve, and payment of same is based on 10 teaching months in the year, at the rate of $70 per month, payable at the end of each quarter. A cheque for the amount of $70 has been forwarded for the quarter ended September 30th, last, and at the end of June, 1929, which will complete the 10 months in the year, the full salary at the above rate will have been paid. I would point out that if salary was paid on a 12 months basis, the amount due each month would be $58.33.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Ferris,

You will note in Agent Robert's letter of November 3rd that he states that the foreman, Mr. A. G. Fields, who was in charge of the erection of the Tobique School apparently was absent at weekends, going home on Saturday afternoon, not returning on the job until Monday noon and sometimes Tuesday and Wednesday. Red Ranks, N.B., November 21st, 1927.

Dear Sir,

I beg to submit herewith the final labour returns of the Tobique School Addition, amounting to $483.50; this makes a total expenditure for labour of $3054.60 and the Departmental cheques I received amounts to $2900.00 leaving a balance due me of $154.60. Kindly forward cheque to cover balance.

The two class rooms are completed, and they look fine, and the teaching Sisters are well pleased with everything, the desks are installed, and the blackboards are all arranged also two cupboards, one in each class room, the domestic science room requires a sewing table to be made also a cupboard to complete this room, there was not sufficient lumber left to build this with, and I did not want to keep Mr. Fields for this small job.

I recommend for your approval and authority to purchase four hundred feet of finished lumber at $30. per thousand and a carpenter to build the table and cupboard required for the domestic science room, it should not require a carpenter over two days.

The new school house is a big improvement for educational purposes, and to the Indian Point Village, the Indians should benefit by the establishment now arranged for their children, the Reverend Principal Teacher informed me that the number of pupils to attend school are thirty or more for each school room, the statistics show a substantial increased population at the Tobique Point.

Test. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs. Your obedient servant,
Ottawa.

Memorandum:

HONOURABLE CHARLES STEWART

With reference to the enclosed letter from Mr. Foster, concerning Mr. A. G. Fields' account, I believe it advisable to let you have a report and to ask for your direction.

Mr. A. G. Fields, who was appointed foreman for the construction of the addition to the Tobique Indian Day School, has been paid at the rate of $8 per day. He has had steady employment since June 20th and time sheets have been forwarded, showing that he has received $8 per day for every working day from that time until the 17th instant. Mr. Indian Agent Roberts, on the 3rd instant, reported that Mr. Fields left the job on Saturdays in the afternoon, in time to reach his home in Woodstock, a distance of 60 miles, to spend the weekend, and that he did not return on the job until Monday noon and sometimes Tuesday and Wednesday. As Mr. Fields has been paid for all the time lost at week ends, I do not consider that he is entitled to mileage for the use of his car. On the 13th instant the Department instructed the Indian Agent to inform Mr. Fields that we regretted favourable consideration to the account could not be given.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on my recent visit to Tobique Indian Reserve, N.B.

Day School

The school building was recently enlarged and is not yet completed. The basement under the new addition is to be arranged for a domestic science classroom. It is about 36' x 26' but in the construction of the addition, due to improper planning, several pillars have been placed down the centre of the floor thus spoiling the appearance and usefulness of an otherwise large room.

I note also that there is a common drinking cup at both the boys' and girls' basins. The basin has outlets for two taps, hot and cold. The hot water side is, of course, not used. I would suggest that a drinking fountain be placed on each of these basins so that cups will not be needed.

C. C. Parker.
Inspector.
Ottawa, May 4th, 1928.

Sir:

An officer of this Department, who visited the Tobique Indian Day School in March, last, states that he noted there was a common drinking cup at both the boys' and girls' basins and at each basin there is an outlet for two taps - hot and cold water. The hot water taps are, of course, not used, and it is suggested that these taps could also be made available for cold water use, to which could be attached drinking fountains of the bubbling type, so that individual cups would not be required.

I shall be pleased if you will furnish a report as to whether fountains of the type suggested could be attached to the taps provided for hot water purposes, and, if so, the approximate cost of having same installed in both the boys' and girls' basins. A local plumber would, no doubt, be able to state whether it would be advisable to install the fountains as suggested and to give you an estimate of the cost. I should be pleased to have your early reply regarding the providing of drinking fountains for this school.

Your obedient servant,

I have to inform you that the new staff appointed at the Tobique school and hospital will take charge on July 1st, next. Sister M. Praxides will take charge as principal, Sister M. Quentin, as assistant, and Sister M. Clare, R.H., will be in charge of the hospital work.

I have to request that you will have the Rev. Sisters at present in charge prepare, in detail, an inventory of all Government property on hand in the hospital and school. This list should show all linens, dishes, towels, cutlery, furniture, hospital and school equipment. Four copies of this inventory should be prepared. Please forward two copies to Rev. Father Ryan, Red Bank, N.B., and one copy to the Department. The other copy should be retained on file in your office.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

C. J. Roberts, T.D.,
Indian Agent,
Red Rapids, N.B.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF REV. F. C. RYAN, INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS FOR THE PROVINCE OF NEW BRUNSWICK, ON HIS VISIT TO THE TOBIQUE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

The exterior of the combined teachers' residence and hospital requires painting very badly. It is too late this fall, but early next spring this should be done. The exterior is certainly in bad shape. There is nothing but knots, knots everywhere. Let the sun and rain get at same, you will certainly then have a proposition on your hands.
Ottawa, October 25th, 1928.

Sir:

Rev. F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of New Brunswick, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tobique Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the domestic science room in the basement of the day school building. He states that this room is filled up with old desks, rubbish, etc., and has requested that instructions be given that this room be at once cleared out and put in good order, as he states that the teaching of domestic science forms the most important work for the benefit of the Indian children.

I have, therefore, to request that you will arrange to have this room thoroughly cleared out. If the old desks are of no further use, they should be broken up. All rubbish should be removed and destroyed. The Department will expect to hear at an early date that this room has been placed in proper order and meets with the approval of the Sister in charge of the teaching of domestic science.

The Inspector has also drawn attention to the number of permits granted to Indian children of school age to remain at home. He recommends that, in future, before a permit is issued, the Rev. Sister Superior be consulted. I may add, it is expected that all children of school age and in good health will attend school regularly.

It is presumed that you have arranged for the purchase of the various articles as mentioned in official letter of September 8th, last. If so, the accounts covering the cost should be forwarded in duplicate, properly certified, in order that payment can be made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

The teacher of the junior room in the Tobique Indian Day School has requested, through Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for New Brunswick, that several extra desks be supplied in order to provide seating accommodation for all the children who will attend. The desks at present in use in this room were obtained from the Globe Furniture Co., Ltd., Waterloo, Ont. They manufacture desks in the following sizes:

Sir:

Rev. F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of New Brunswick, in a report on his recent inspection of the Tobique Indian Day School, makes the following recommendations:

1. That the exterior of the hospital and teachers' residence be painted.

2. That the interior of the school building (both rooms) be thoroughly cleaned and all woodwork well washed, and the floors thoroughly scrubbed and, when dry, given two coats of hot oil, and that this work be done by a competent man.

3. That the ceiling of the domestic science room be covered with beaver board, and the concrete floor given two good coats of paint, as it is very dusty.

4. That the walls of the domestic science room be given a coat of alabastine.

5. That 12 chairs be supplied for the domestic science room.

6. That 2 drinking cups, attached to chains, be supplied.

In connection with the above recommendations of the Inspector, I have to request that you will furnish a report as to whether you would approve of any of this work being undertaken. If so, you should give an approximate estimate of the cost in each case, and you should also state if you can arrange to have the work carried out by day labour. You should give the above matters your early attention and furnish the information asked for, as, if it is decided to carry out any of the work, it should be completed before the schools reopen after the summer holidays.

The Inspector also states that the Rev. Sister Superior drew his attention to the use by the janitor of an outside door leading out of the domestic science room. She states that he opens this door and in the winter it makes the floors of the school very cold. The Rev. Sister considers that this door should be closed up in winter and the janitor enter by the furnace room or through the back entrance to the school. The Inspector states that the Rev. Sister could explain this matter to you, and you might take it up with her and arrange that the difficulty mentioned be satisfactorily adjusted next winter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. H. MacPhail, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Perth, N.B.

Ottawa, July 24th, 1929.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 19th instant, relative to the painting, repairs, etc., required to the teachers' residence, hospital and domestic science room in the day school building on the Tobique reserve. Relative to the painting of the exterior of the hospital and teachers' residences, I have to say that the Department has no funds to pay the cost of having this work done during the present year and this matter will have to stand over until next spring.

Relative to the cleaning of the interior of the school building (both rooms), I have to say that you may arrange to have the woodwork well washed and the floors thoroughly scrubbed and, when dry, given two coats of hot oil. You may purchase a half barrel of Imperial floor dressing, the same to be applied, when necessary, by the caretaker of the school.

You may arrange to have the ceiling of the domestic science room covered with Gyproc and the floor given two coats of a suitable type of paint for the purpose. You may, also, have the walls and ceiling given a coat of alabastine.

You are authorized to arrange for the purchase of 12 chairs suitable for use in the domestic science room. They should be of a substantial make and as inexpensive as possible. You may, also, supply two drinking cups, attached to chains.

You may, also, arrange to have a small porch erected and a storm door placed on the outside door leading out of the domestic science room. It is not intended that any unnecessary expense be incurred for this purpose.

You should purchase all the materials required for the above-authorized work and see that it is carried out by competent labour, all expenses being kept within the estimate given by you. All of this work should be completed before the school reopens after the present summer holidays and you should, therefore, give the matter your prompt attention and have the work started at an early date. When these improvements are completed, you should forward properly certified accounts, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the supplying of materials, also, for the labour employed.

The Department does not consider it necessary, at the present time, to have a storm porch erected on the verandah over the main entrance to the school.

Your obedient servant,

N. H. MacPhail, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Perth, N.B.

Sir:

Rev. F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools, in a report on his inspection in June, last, of the Tobique Indian Day School, recommends that the interior woodwork of the classrooms be washed and the walls and ceiling brushed down, also that the floors be thoroughly scrubbed and allowed to dry, after which they should be given a coat of hot oil. He also states that a number of window shades are required for the school. You should arrange, during the present summer holidays, to see that the classrooms are thoroughly cleaned, the floors given a coat of hot oil and this school placed in a cleanly condition before it re-opens. If any window blinds are required, you may arrange for their purchase and installation.

Father Ryan also requests that a sand table be supplied for use in the primary department. You may arrange to have a sand table, of the size and type required, built locally and installed in the classroom, where desired by the Rev. Sister in charge. It might be well for you to consult the Rev. Sister as to the type of table that would be satisfactory and you could then have same built by a local carpenter.

Please keep all costs in connection with the above work, authorized for this school, as low as possible. When the cleaning has been carried out and the table supplied, you should forward accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

In reply I have to say that you may arrange to have the earth in the rear section of the basement removed. Mr. Smith,

The McPhail Indian Agent told me I had to go and work two days a week for relief. Will he let me work painting the church? I am a painter by trade. I found out late by the letters you sent to the Indians that only Public work was compulsory, and I would like to get my wages for the work I did in church. I ruined my clothes on the job and instead of giving me something so I could get some clothes which I need badly, he goes and cuts my relief from $5 to $4 dollars. Myself and wife and baby $3 dollars. My brother he put to board with me was getting here now he gets only $1 a week. Can't board a man for that he is starving as well. I've asked for
more for him but McPhail refused to give it. Then I told him he would have to get another place for him. He said if I put him out he would cut my relief. I was good enough to work my trade in relief but I do wish you could arrange it so I could get some clothes. I need them and I can't buy them out of my relief. I worked at the church painted the church inside work it took 3 coats of paint and wood work. If it was contracted it would cost them around a hundred dollars. I worked 15 days there it came to from $4 to $6 dollar a day.

In regards to the convent here on the reserve I hear they are going to paint it - if so I would like to get the job of painting it - I would work for $8 per day 9 hours and let the gov't furnish the paints and stuff needed. It would be a lot cheaper and just as good a work done.

Hoping to get an answer direct to me if you answer through McPhail I get no satisfaction.

Your very truly,

May 28, 1932.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

The question has arisen as to what primary allotment in this year's Appropriation should be used for a water tank at the Topique hospital and teachers' residence—a combined building. I believe it is now timely for the Medical portion of the Vote to undertake somewhat more of the expenditure than in the past.

Upon reviewing the costs at this school, I find that for the five years ended March 31, 1925, the average yearly expenditure for all purposes for the two-classroom Indian day school was $991.00. During the fiscal years 1923-24 and 1924-25 the hospital and teachers' residence was erected at a cost to Indian Education of $22,670. I believe at this time some of the furnishing, which was additional, was charged to the Medical portion of the New Brunswick Vote. This charge on Indian Education was at least $15,000 more than if we had built a teachers' residence only.

With reference to the current expenses since that time, I believe that they have averaged $3,464 for the past six years. This was at least $1,500 more per year than if a day school only was being operated. Half of this extra expense, of course, is the salary of the third teacher. One of the Sisters is so classified, but, as a matter of fact, her duties are those of nurse and field matron.

I propose to discuss this with Dr. Stone, with a view to a more fair apportioning of the costs in future. In view of the difficulties of changing the classification of the third worker, I suggest that $600 or $700 of the miscellaneous expenses be paid from Medical primary allotment.

Sir:

You quote as your authority for the purchase official letters dated April 30, 1931, and May 1, 1931. In letter of May 1, 1931, authority was given to purchase 6 window curtains. We have been unable, however, to find any authority to purchase 6 rollers for maps; at a total cost of $17.10. The Department does not furnish equipment of this kind for Indian day schools. All maps supplied are mounted on wooden rollers, which is considered sufficient. You should explain the reason for the delay in forwarding the accounts, also state on whose authority the rollers for the maps were obtained.

Our funds this year are extremely limited, and, before any purchase is made, the Principal of the school should make requisition through your office and you should receive the necessary authority, also all accounts covering purchases for the school should be forwarded by you, properly certified, not later than one month after the purchase has been made. By withholding accounts as in this instance, the Department is misled as to the amount of funds that will be required for the current expenses of the school during the year.

Payment of the account will be withheld until your explanation is received regarding the purchase of the rollers for the maps and as to the delay in forwarding the account, it being over a year since authority for the purchase of some of the supplies was granted.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Some years ago, the Department erected a new school building on the Tobique Reserve (No. 20). The cost of this building was paid wholly from the Appropriation for Indian Education, and, in addition, any repairs made since the building was erected have been paid from the same source.

Part of the building has always been devoted to hospital purposes. Three Reverend Sisters are employed, one of whom devotes all her time to the work of the hospital. Her salary has also been paid from the Appropriation for Indian Education.

I have discussed this matter with Dr. Stone, and I would appreciate your concurrence in the following:

1. From April 1, 1934, any disbursements in connection with the repairs or upkeep of the part of the building devoted to hospital purposes should be paid from Medical Vote.

2. The salary of the Rev. Sister engaged in hospital work should be provided in the Medical Vote for the fiscal year 1935-36 (from April 1, 1935). I understand that there is no provision for her in the Medical Vote for 1934-35, and we have provided for her salary during that fiscal year.

Approved by

Dr. McGill.

To: Dept. Of Ind. Affairs,

Aug 6th 1936

Dear Sir,

Few days ago, I was looking over the Tobique Indian day school, and discovered that it really needs painting very bad, another year would be worse. As an Indian agent being away, I cannot draw his attention to it. So I thought that I would bring this matter with the Department so, I can invite work, for some of the Indians.

I am a sign painter, and am able to mix any kind of paint required for building purpose. Many of the members are out of work, and besides it would be best to paint now before school opens up.

Just say the word, and I'll measure the building and send you the actual measurements, total cost of material etc. At present I'm out of work. I have been painting buildings at Perth and Andover, besides signs, trucks etc. My references will be furnished on request. I am cordially waiting for immediate reply.

Yours Very Truly,

Charles Paulie,
Ojibwe.
