Dear Mr. MacPhail:

Will you please apply to the Indian Department School Branch, for electric lighting for our two classrooms. Some days are so dark that we really need lights the greater part of the day, and Dr. McIntosh says it is an urgent need as the lights would eliminate so much eye strain. There are lights now in the basement, and for very little extra cost two drop lights could be provided in each of the two class rooms.

Kindly rush this appeal through to the proper authority as quickly as possible.

Yours very sincerely,

Prin.

Sister Honora
Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find letter from Sister Honora, Principal Tobique Indian Day School requesting that electric lights be installed in the two class rooms of the school.

I have obtained an estimate from George W. Wright, local electrician who states that $30 will cover cost of labour and materials for installing two lights in each classroom.

I would ask that I be authorized to have this work done at once as the rooms are very dark a good part of the day at this particular time of year.

Your obedient servant,

N.H. MacPhail, Indian Agent.

Sir,

Painting interior Tobique School

In reply to letter #55-2-11 dated July 6th, I beg to submit the following estimate given me by a local paint contractor:

| Item                        | Quantity | Price   |
|-----------------------------|----------|---------|
| 10 Gals. Interior Gloss Paint |          | $47.50  |
| 75 Lbs. White Alabastine    |          | 7.50    |
| Extra's                     |          | 5.00    |
| Labour                      |          |         |

Total: $210.00

I think the above estimate high. My estimate for materials was only 7 Gals. and I think I could get the job done for around $100.00. However there are two classrooms 21x35' with 15' ceiling, sheathed up 3ft. with 4 large connecting doors and 6 large windows (double) in each room. In addition there are two entrance halls and two toilets in basement.

Any washing or preparatory work can be done by Indian women but I would not care to have the painting done by Indian labour. I doubt if any of them would be available in any case.

If the Department is prepared to authorize this work I would ask that they use the painters' estimate and I will keep the cost as low as possible.

Your obedient servant,

N. H. MacPhail, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Ottawa,
August 13, 1942.

E.A.D.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant, you may arrange for the painting of the interior of the Tobique Indian Day School. It is noted from your letter that you have received a quotation of $210.00 for material and labour but that you consider you can have the work done at a lower cost. The Department will look forward, with interest, to seeing how much you can reduce this expenditure.

It is also noted that Indian labour will not be available, but if you can secure Indians you should use them. With regard to white labour, you should employ those on the approved list.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, May 17, 1948.

Memorandum:

Colonel E. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Training.

Re: Wiring of Day School and Teachers' Residence.

I wish to advise that during my last visit to the Tobique Reserve, I discovered that there were a number of extensions made to the wiring in the basements of both the buildings by a person, or persons, who were unqualified to do so. There is always danger of fire because of a short circuit.

I instructed Superintendent MacPhail to obtain the services of a qualified electrician and have him check all this wiring and, if it is found to be dangerous, to cut off the current until such time as the necessary repairs can be made. Mr. MacPhail, no doubt, will report his findings in the near future.

J. E. Morris,
Acting Inspector Indian Agencies.

Mr. N. H. MacPhail,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Perth, New Brunswick.

Tobique Indian Day School.

We have received a report that a number of extensions have been made to the wiring in the basements of both the school and the teacherage located on the Tobique Reserve. If these extensions were made by unqualified persons, the Department feels that a real danger of fire exists. Would you therefore please arrange to obtain the services of a qualified electrician and have him check all this wiring. If it is found to be dangerous, the power must be cut off until such time as the necessary repairs can be made.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

July 6, 1948

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Ottawa

Dear Sir:

I wish to advise that I have been given an approximate estimate of from $1000 to $1200 to remove the old stone wall and replace it with cement, under one-half of Tobique School, as follows:

| Item                          | Cost   |
|-------------------------------|--------|
| Removing old wall             | $350.00|
| Jacking and supporting building| 100.00 |
| Building form and new wall    | 250.00 |
| Cement and lumber             | 300.00 |

This work is urgent, as one end of the stone wall is caving, allowing the building to settle, and I do not think that the present foundation could be repaired satisfactorily.

If this expenditure meets with the approval of the Department, I would ask that you forward a cheque for $800.00 to cover cost of labour, as the work should be done during the next two months.

N. H. MacPhail, Supt.,
Northern N. B. Agency

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Tobique Indian Day School, New Brunswick
North Indian Agency, Electoral District
of Victoria-Carleton.

Superintendent MacPhail reports that one end of the stone wall at the Tobique School is sinking and consequently allowing the building to settle. He states that it is not possible to satisfactorily repair it.

Mr. MacPhail recommends that the old stone wall be removed and replaced with cement. The cost of this work is estimated at a maximum of $1,200.00.

Superintendent MacPhail recommends the employment of three white men, Richard Wallace, Gregory Hudson and James Wallace whose addresses are Perth, New Brunswick. Richard Wallace has previously built several veterans' houses on the Tobique Reserve.

I would appreciate it if the Minister would approve the expenditure mentioned above and also the employment of the men mentioned.

Director.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION
Tobique Indian Day School.

There are two rooms in operation at Tobique. Nineteen pupils were present in the Senior room and twenty-six in the Junior. The reading of the pupils was fairly fluent but the teaching of the subject is very traditional. As in many of the schools no definite training of the physical aspects of reading have been undertaken. The Indian child has certain muscular deficiencies which prevents the pronunciation of sounds. This can be overcome only by muscular exercise in order to train and produce these sounds.

The weaving and sewing are quite satisfactory. The pupils enjoy this work, and a demonstration was made of the methods of interpreting this work with the academic. I feel that by this means many of the lessons in the classroom will become meaningful.

Good work is being done at this school and while I did not check all the academic subjects, I am satisfied that progress is being made.

The exterior of the residence is badly in need of paint. This should be done if at all possible this season as deterioration is liable to take place. This residence is part hospital and part residence. In fact, the complete main floor and part of the basement is used for hospital charges. Whether the Medical Branch will assume any obligation for the up-keep of this building or not, I can not say. I feel that they have a definite responsibility there.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Vocational Training.

Memorandum:

Inspection Report
Tobique Indian Day School

Date of Inspection - September 16, 1949.

Teachers - Sister M. Victoire with a Second Class Certificate, five years of Provincial and five years of Indian experience. Sister M. Honora with a First Class Certificate, ten years of Indian and eleven years of Provincial experience.

School Building -

This is a two-room school with folding doors between the classrooms. The two rooms are bright and attractive with fair space for the number of children enrolled now. However, when the children return from Maine, it is obvious that an extra classroom will be required.

Classroom Activities -

(a) Senior Room - Sister Honora is doing a first rate job of teaching. The pupils tested well and I spent some time indicating how the vocabulary and language work could be improved. Her discipline is good and the pupils are interested in their work. She has a large number of boys attending and they are working hard.

(b) Junior Room - Sister Victoire is also a capable teacher and handles her class well. The high grades one and two speaking out more loudly and more clearly than many classrooms I have inspected. They read well - and in phrases and sentences. There is no word calling and she stresses this from the beginner classes up.

This is one of the better schools we have in our system and the credit is largely due to the calibre of teachers employed.

Recommendations -

1. That a third classroom be opened this Fall in the basement. There is a domestic science classroom, and heating is adequate. As electricity is available, a primary room could be operated here for the winter.

2. Mr. Doucet should visit this school and decide how a third and possibly a fourth classroom could be added.

3. Send census form to Mr. MacPhail so that the potential pupilage can be determined.

Bernard P. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Memorandum:

COLONEL NEARY

Tobique Indian Day School

The Tobique School is in a fairly well conserved condition. One difficulty in heating the rooms is the excessive height of the ceilings. This of course could be fairly easily remedied. Some repair will be necessary to the plaster. This should not be expensive for I believe that the present plaster is sufficiently good to justify repairing.

Appended to this report is the number of pupils from the age of 6 to 16 years. The present enrolment is 80 and there appears to be no great change in this enrolment for at least five years. From the figures given in this appended summary it appears that the addition of one classroom would adequately satisfy the educational needs of this reserve for the next ten years. The present plan lends itself readily to the addition of a third classroom giving it the shape of an L. The third classroom windows would be facing south which would give adequate lighting. Below this classroom a well organized Manual Training shop could be devised.

I would then suggest that an architect proceed at the earliest convenience to Tobique and make the plans so that this construction may be undertaken as
soon as weather permits. The rough lumber could be obtained from the reserve at the approximate cost of $32.00 per thousand. The heating system could readily be changed into a forced air heating system. Our mode of construction should be decided as soon as possible so that Superintendent MacPhail may be given an advance to have the lumber prepared.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor of Vocational Training.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

The Tobique Indian Day School is situated near Perth, N.B., and the Restigouche Indian Day School is situated near Campbellton, N.B.

Tobique School - The Tobique Indian Day School is a two-room school with a third class presently being conducted in the basement. We are anxious to make a one-room addition to this building and would appreciate a visit from one of your architects so that the necessary plans and specifications can be prepared. The present plan lends itself readily to the addition of a third classroom which would give the building the shape of an L. The windows of this third classroom would be facing the south which would ensure adequate lighting. Below this classroom a well organized Manual Training shop could be installed in the basement. Mr. Indian Superintendent MacPhail lives at Perth and will be able to take the architect out to the school so that the necessary plans can be prepared.

Restigouche School - This is a five-room building and we are conducting a sixth class in the nearby provincial school. Two of the classrooms provided are...
very small having been devised when the building was modified.

We wish to extend this building in the form of an H thereby adding two classrooms and enlarging the two small ones. Mr. Indian Superintendent Nadeau lives at Restigouche and arrangements could be made to meet the architect when he arrives at Campbellton which is two miles away.

Both of these projects are readily accessible and are not too far apart. It would be appreciated if you could have an architect proceed to these schools to draft plans and specifications for these required additions. If further details are needed they can be obtained from the Education Division of this Branch.

Dear Mr. Jones:

I was called to the Tobique Reservation yesterday by the Chief and Father Sam who had several complaints to make.

I understand that the building of two welfare houses was started. The basements are in but they have not had any further word to go ahead.

At the school. The engineer and inspector were there taking measurements for a 30 foot wing to be built on the school and said the work would start right away, but nothing has been heard since. I do not agree with the engineer's plan to build this wing as it is on the wrong side of the building. They have three teachers now with two classrooms. I understand one of these teachers is only temporary. There will be 90 children starting this fall and 50 more next fall so they are quite crowded.

They told me that an educational representative from Ottawa was there this spring and told them to get 8 boys and girls ready to go to vocation school or a higher grade school and everything would be arranged. Nothing more has been heard about this and they have the boys and girls all ready.

The foundation of the pump house needs to be looked after at once, otherwise it is apt to undermine the house which will slide into the river. Although there is ledge at this point they did not dig down to it and there is about 5 feet of loose gravel between the concrete bottom of the pump house and the ledge. The side next to the river has been washed away and it should be wharfed up at once to save further damage.

I was asked to bring these matters to your attention with the hopes that you might give them prompt attention.

Thanking you

Yours very truly,

(signed) H.H. Hatfield
Victoria-Carleton.

Dear Mr. [Name],

I am writing to place before the Department the need of a dwelling on this Reserve for the teacher.

From Sept. 1913 till Sept. 1914, I had rooms in an Indian home, rented and furnished by the Dept., at the end of the first quarter of this Indian Year, would not longer rent his rooms unless the rent was raised from $2 per month to $5 per month. In other words, $60 per year. Paying such rent seemed absurd. The cost of a small dwelling was be paid out in the course of ten or twelve years, and at the end of that time the teacher's quarters would still be uncertain. The money paid in rent seemed lost. Nothing permanent in the way of living quarters for the teacher was got out of it, and living in part of an Indian home was a form more or less satisfactory as a dwelling would be.

I again attempted to board at the home of the missionary on the Reserve, as I had before. In Sept. 1913, the hope was put under repair, and this, with the fact that there was no housekeeper, excepting the part I had to take,

gave up, and since Oct. last have been looking for a home off the Reserve and across the Ottawa River. This is only a make-shift and inconvenient in many ways. Crossing in a canoe in pleasant weather might be agreeable but is quite different in December and January. There was no ice for crossing at all. The river began rising in October and that evening during a cold driving snowstorm I had to walk around the schoolhouse to find a bridge—a distance of four miles. Luckily the next day we could not have been able to have school the following day.

The only alternative to living off the Reserve is to get work again at an Indian home. From experience this also is nothing better than a make-shift and I need hardly say that living in a one-roomed rent in the Indian home cannot be satisfactory. But this is what must be under present conditions if the teacher tries to live on the Reserve and this I contemplate doing before the breaking up of the ice.

I will not again consider trying to board at the home of the mission lady. This household is uncertain and as far as I know is not one where the teacher can get necessary rest. During the year, excepting for my efforts, it was several times without a housekeeper.

I do not expect anything in the way

NEW BRUNSWICK

No residence for teacher provided. One is much needed and has been asked for.

No blinds or shutters except what maps do.

Ethel F. McGrand,
Teacher.
Dear Sir,

Your reply to my letter of Jan. 26th in which I asked for the erection of a dwelling for the teacher in connection with the Tobique Indian school, was received several weeks since and I waited with much hope, your asking the Agent, Mr. W. written for an estimate of the cost. Your reply to this came to definitely set it aside. I have here forwarded the Department with suggestions and hope now that you will hear with a few remarks. I only feel the need of this building, and consequently may be more urgent than any who may recommend it.

McLaughlin and Luff's estimate was high and destroys all hope of having any in this way before another winter. As to the building, a second story is not necessary. Rather a dwelling consisting of a bungalow is more desirable and could be erected, I understand for less cost.

At present I am living in one room of
an Indian house. This room 18½ ft x 10½ ft x 7 ft must furnish living and sleeping apartments. The house built some thirty years ago is not very comfortable and it will require considerable courage to undertake an entire winter in it should it be as severe as our winters usually are. This was exceptionally mild.

It took much time and labor to make the room, in some small measure, fit to live in. The owner is a person of whom and in the course of a year may feel that she cannot longer rent. I have had this sad experience here. It has few comforts, and the uncertainty after so much labor, does not add any. The need of a teacher's residence has always been in evidence, but work experience, conditions have reached a limit.

I noted in your reply to my letter that my salary would be slightly increased. This is some recognition of my difficulty, but I would prefer that which would ensure rent in my house outside of the schoolroom, to increase of salary.

Trusting that I may not seem unreasonable, I can only ask again that this
is sincerely considered and some hope given that something will be done in this direction, at your earliest possible convenience, which I trust will not be in a too distant future.

Respectfully Yours,

[Signature]

Sir,

Regarding the plans and specifications for the teachers residence on the Tobique Reserve, I have looked over same and I note it calls for a foundation of cedar and the building is to be sheathed inside instead of plastered.

I might mention that we have in this country very cold winters and if it could be arranged to have a concrete foundation instead of cedar, it would make a permanent foundation and be very much warmer. I would also strongly advise that the building be plastered instead of sheathed, as it would help to make the house a great deal warmer. I do not think the expense would be very much greater than if sheathed. And by putting in a concrete foundation, I do not believe it would exceed $200.00 more than it would cost for the cedar foundation.

I also note that specifications do not call for hardwood floors, and as it is going to be the home of the teacher, whoever it may be, I am of the opinion it would be much more comfortable and would last better if they were made of hardwood.

I will be pleased to hear from you regarding same as soon as possible.

Mr. Scott,

Rev. Father Ryan and the Indian Agent have several times brought to the attention of the Department the necessity for a teacher's residence at the Tobique Indian Day School.

In the Spring of 1919 the Department advertised for tenders for the erection of a teacher's residence at this point and the lowest tender received was for $1,350.00. As the Department's architect estimated the cost of erecting a suitable building at $800.00, the work was not proceeded with last year. Mr. Agent Wooten, under cover of a letter dated July 30th, 1920, states that Joseph Ellis has a good property on the reserve which he offers to sell to the Department for $700.00, which the agent states is a remarkably low price. Ottawa, June 1, 1922.

Memorandum for File.

Rev. Father Hugolin, of the Tobique Reserve, N.B., visited the Department today and was exceedingly pleased to learn that we were providing for a teacher's residence for the Indian day school. In the Supplementary Estimates for the current year there is an item of $1500 for this purpose.

The Rev. Father strongly urges the appointment of two Sisters, one to act as teacher and the other as field matron; and this fact should be kept in mind when the plans for the bungalow are being drawn. I have intimated that we will correspond with the Rev. Father Ryan in this connection and that the salary allowed the Sisters will be at the rate of $550 plus bonus, each. It may be necessary, to save advertising the position through the Civil Service Commission, to engage both Sisters as school teachers.

These Sisters will quite likely be available by September first, 1923.

Father Hugolin has intimated that the present incumbent - Miss Nellie Dugan - is about to resign, and I have asked him to correspond with Rev. Father Ryan regarding a successor.

Supt. of Indian Education.
OTTAWA, June 5, 1922.

Reverend Sir,

Reverend Father Hugolin, of the Tobique Reserve, visited the Department a few days ago and strongly urged the appointment of two Sisters, one to act as teacher and the other as field matron on that Reserve. He stated that it was quite likely that the services of these Sisters would be available by September 1, 1923. If the services of the Sisters are secured, it will be necessary to provide proper accommodation for them.

We have this year an item in our Supplementary Estimates for the purpose of providing a small bungalow for a teacher in connection with this school, but, if the Sisters are engaged, more extensive living accommodation will have to be provided than is contained in a bungalow. Father Hugolin also stated that it was the intention of the church authorities to ask for the removal of the school to another site, as the church desired to obtain from the Indians the land on which the school now stands for church purposes. Father Hugolin stated that he would let the Department know in the course of the present summer the definite arrangements that are being made regarding the securing of the teachers and the moving of the school, and when this information is received we will then be in position to go on with the work of putting up a residence for the Sisters. We intimated to Father Hugolin that we would inform you regarding the above mentioned matters. I might say that if the Sisters are engaged, we would be prepared to allow them a salary at the rate of $550 per annum, plus any bonus provided by law.

Father Hugolin intimated that the present teacher, Miss Nellie Dugan, intends to resign at the end of June. It will, therefore, be necessary to obtain the services of another teacher to succeed her until such time as the services of the Sisters can be obtained. If Miss Dugan resigns, you should endeavour to secure the services of another teacher, and the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher selected by you should be forwarded for the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated August 22nd, No. 66-2-8, instant. I may say that Mr. Charles W. Bowlin has started the work on the basement. I believe Mr. Bowlin understands his work as a contractor and will do his best to have the work, and the material furnished in the building to the best satisfaction.

I want to make a suggestion in regards to the plans and specifications of the basement wall, in this part of the Globe we have to contend with very intense frost and it has always been the practice here in this part of country when building a concrete wall, to have it built with a batter on the outside, about a quarter of an inch to the foot, according to the plans this is a straight 15 inch wall. I would suggest that the wall be 15 inches thick at the bottom, and taper from the outside to a thickness of say 10 or 12 inches at the top of the wall, by doing this the frost when drawing out of clay ground, would naturally draw away from a tapered wall and could not do any damage.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

With further reference to your letter of January 31st ultimo No. 66-2-3, also my reply of March 26, in connection with the source of water supply for the new hospital and combined teacher's residence on the Tobique Reserve,

I beg to inform the Department that I have been considering a much better and cheaper water system than I had recommended in my letter of above date.

We could get a good and sufficient supply of water from a well drilled right near the building, within 20 or thirty feet of the building, and install a good air pressure water system in the basement of the building, that would supply the water direct from the well to the faucets all through the building at whatever pressure required, from 40 to 60 lbs pressure whatever was needed, and could be automatically operated by a small dynamo installed in the basement. I would recommend this source of water supply, from a drilled well, and forced through the building with a good up-to-date air pressure system. This would cost approximately $600.00 to drill the well and install the water system. I would recommend the well being drilled immediately, and have all underground water pipes ready to connect to the basement when the basement walls are completed, in order to test the plumber's work. The water system should be installed before his work is completed.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,

Sir—

In reply to your letter of the 26th ultimo, I beg to enclose herewith a new scheme as outlined by the contractor Mr C.W.Bowlin for the proposal and the estimate of a complete drainage and sewage system from the new combine and teacher's residence and hospital on the Tobique Reserve.

You will note that the contractor Mr Bowlin, does not approve of the sewage running to the river bank as outlined in his letter, in looking the situation over and the condition of the ground I have decided and would recommend to the Department the building of a cesspool as outlined in Mr Bowlin's letter, at the cost of $650.00 for labor and material to complete a 6" vitrified drain pipe line a distance of 100 feet from the building connecting with the main sewage in the basement at a depth of five feet with a grade of not exceeding 1/4" per length of pipe, and to enter the cesspool at a height of 6ft, from the bottom inside.

The cesspool to be dug out a depth of 16 feet and 12 feet square and walled with cider not less than 8" at the top and properly framed together, and supported in the centre, and a cider top with centre bearings and covered over level with three feet of earth, making it level with the ground surface.

This cesspool will take care of all sewage without any trouble in that gravel ground and will last at least 20 years and if any trouble occurs in the drainage pipe it can be easily located, with very little expense.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department regarding the well drilled for the combine teacher's residence and hospital on the Tobique Reserve last November. The well was drilled down a depth of 64 feet with about 60 feet of 6 inch steel casing, and water was located and we got a flow of 15 feet up from the bottom of the well, which was considered a good and sufficient supply of water, and about one month from the time the well was drilled I had the Canadian Fair-Banks Morse, Co., to install their pump and pneumatic tank water system, and at that time we discovered after installing the pump and had it working, and about two strokes of the pump the well was practically dry no water, it was discovered that quick-sand had entered by way of the water vain, and reached a height of six feet in the bottom of the well, thereby shutting off the water flow.

The only remedy was to do at the time was to leave it for the time being, as the cold weather would not permit any further drilling of the well, as the drilling machine would not work satisfactory in cold weather.

The well driller claims the only thing to do is to drill this well down further, he thinks from experience it will be necessary to go between 20 or 30 feet this depth should get clear of the quick-sand and get a good flow of water, he will not be allowed to charge anything for moving his machine, as this is an understood agreement in a case of this kind, when sufficient water is not secured, although he will have to be paid for the number of feet he continues to drill, and the number feet of casing he drives.

I would recommend to the Department to have this done as soon as the weather permits.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs.
